title: Content Filter on RV0xx Series Routers
description:
This video explains how to configure content filter on RV0xx Series Routers. Content Filtering can block access to specific websites based on domain name or characters in the URL.
For more information on RV016: http://cs.co/jlbYTrv016.
For more information on RV042: http://cs.co/jlbYTrv042.
For more information on RV042G: http://cs.co/jlbYTrv42G.
For more information on RV082: http://cs.co/jlbYTrv082.
Subscribe to Cisco's YouTube channel: http://cs.co/Subscribe.
transcript: welcome today we will demonstrate how to configure content filtering on rv0 series routers content filtering prevents clients connected to the router from accessing specific websites access to websites can be denied through domain names or by keywords in the URL content filtering can be turned on and off through the use of scheduling scheduling can activate or deactivate content filtering automatically based on the time of day and the day of the week this video tutorial explains how to configure content filtering on rv016 rv042 rv082 and rv042g VPN routers we will demonstrate this feature on an rv082 router with firmware version 4.2.2 point8 if Cisco protect link is enabled on the device content filtering becomes disabled log into the web Configuration utility from the system summary page click firewall content filter this will bring up the content filter page check the enable block forbidden domain checkbox to allow the router to block access to specific websites after this is checked the content available for this option will become configurable to add a website to the block list enter the domain name of the website in the ad field when finished click add to list if you need to change a domain name in the list select the domain name in the list make any changes in the ad field and click update to delete a domain from the list select the domain and click the delete button check the enable website blocking by keywords checkbox to block websites that have specific characters in their URL after this is checked the content available for this option will become configurable enter the respective keywords of URLs you want to block in the ad fields and click add to list to change a keyword in the list select the keyword and edit the word in the ad field then click update to delete a keyword from the list select the keyword in the list and click the delete button the scheduling section dictates when the content filtering rules will be active by default the rules are always active scheduling can only be configured if either type of content filtering has been activated choose interval from the time drop- down list to specify the time period when the rules are active the from to and effective Fields become configurable when interval is chosen these fields allow you to specify the time and day of the week the rules are active enter the desired time period in hours and minutes in 24-hour notation for the filtering to be active in the from and two fields in the effective on field check the days the rule rul will be active by default everyday is chosen to choose specific days for the rules to be active uncheck the everyday box and check each day the rules will be active when finished click save to save all configurations thank you for watching and for more video tutorials please visit the Cisco YouTube channel

title: Cisco Tech Talk: Restart and Restore on RV0XX Series Routers
description:
This video explains how to restart and restore to factory default on RV0XX Series Routers. Both of these options may be performed with the use of the reset button or by the web configuration utility.
For more information on RV016: http://cs.co/jlbYTrv016.
For more information on RV042: http://cs.co/jlbYTrv042.
For more information on RV042G: http://cs.co/jlbYTrv42G.
For more information on RV082: http://cs.co/jlbYTrv082.
Subscribe to Cisco's YouTube channel: http://cs.co/Subscribe.
transcript: welcome today we will demonstrate how to restart and how to restore to factory defaults on rv0 VPN routers the router should be restarted If it freezes or begins to behave improperly the router should be restored to factory defaults if the device appears to malfunction even after restart has been performed if the login credentials have been lost or if you wish to have all settings restored to their original defaults both of these options may be performed with the use of the reset button or by using the web Configuration utility this video tutorial explains how to restore to factory defaults and rv016 rv042 rv082 and rv042g we will demonstrate how to do this using an rv082 VPN router with firmware version 4.2.2 point8 remember that a restart of the router erases all settings and configurations that have been performed but not saved to the device all settings that have been saved will not be erased to physically restart the device use a PIN to press and hold the reset button on the back of the device for one second you can also unplug the router and plug it back in to restart the device with the web configuration utility log into the router and click system management restart click the restart router button to restart the device a confirmation window will appear asking to confirm the restart click okay to continue after clicking okay a rebooting window appears and the device will reopen the web Configuration utility once it has finished rebooting remember that a restor to factory defaults erases all saved settings and configurations on the router to physically restored to factory defaults use a PIN to press and hold the reset button for 30 seconds during this process the light on the front of the router May begin to flash different colors indicating a restore is taking place to restore def factory defaults with the web Configuration utility log into the router and in the navigation Tree on the left click system management factory default click the return to factory defaults button this restores the device to factory defaults a confirmation box will appear asking to confirm the restore click okay after clicking okay a rebooting window appears and the device will reopen the web Configuration utility once it has finished rebooting thank you for watching and for more video tutorials please visit the Cisco YouTube channel [Music]

title: Content Filtering  Example  on RV0xx Routers
description:
This video provides an example on how Content Filtering on RV0xx routers is used in practice. In this demonstration, a website will be blocked through content filtering.
For more information on RV016: http://cs.co/jlbYTrv016.
For more information on RV042: http://cs.co/jlbYTrv042.
For more information on RV042G: http://cs.co/jlbYTrv42G.
For more information on RV082: http://cs.co/jlbYTrv082.
Subscribe to Cisco's YouTube channel: http://cs.co/Subscribe.
tags: router scheduling PREFERRED PLAYLIST ON CHANNEL -- Small Business
transcript: [Music] Welcome. Today we will demonstrate how content filtering on RV0 series routers is used in practice. To learn more about content filtering, please see the content filter on RV0 series routers video on the Cisco YouTube Small Business playlist. We will demonstrate a content filtering scenario on an RV082VPN router with firmware version 4.2.2.08. In this scenario, a small business wants to block access to Facebook on their network during business hours, which are from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Monday through Friday. In the forbidden domains list, the domain www.fas facebook.com has been added. In the blocked keywords list, the words Facebook, face, and book have been added. In the scheduling section, the blocking interval has been set from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. on weekdays. When an employee attempts to access www.fas.com, a URL blocked message appears on the screen. Should an employee attempt to work around this domain blocking by using an alternative form of the URL such as m.fas.com, the page will also be blocked because of the domain contains keywords that are on the keyword blocking list. Thank you for watching and for more video tutorials, please visit the Cisco YouTube channel. [Music]

title: Dual WAN Configuration on RV0xx Series Routers
description:
This video explains how to configure dual WAN settings on RV0xx Routers. A Wide Area Network is a network that connects multiple LANs together. This video applies to the RV042, RV042G, and RV082.
For more information on RV042: http://cs.co/jlbYTrv042.
For more information on RV042G: http://cs.co/jlbYTrv42G.
For more information on RV082: http://cs.co/jlbYTrv082.

Subscribe to Cisco's YouTube channel: http://cs.co/Subscribe.
transcript: [Music] welcome today we will be configuring dual W connections on rv0 series routers a wide area network or Wan is a network that connects local area networks together the rv042 rv042g and rv082 routers support a dual Wan feature that allows both Wan ports to be used at the same time the Dual Wan connections can also be configured as a failover to ensure continuous internet connectivity these routers also use protocol binding to further optimize the Dual Wan configuration protocol binding allows certain traffic to be sent through a specific Wan Port this video tutorial explains how to configure dual Wan settings on the rv042 rv082 and rv042g VPN routers to demonstrate this process we will use a rv082 router with firmware version 42.280206 connection to the internet port on the router next plug another ethernet cable into the DMZ interet port on the router by default the secondary Wan Port is configured as a secondary ISP W Port this port can also be configured as a DMZ log into the web Configuration utility from the system summary page click system management dual Wan click the appropriate radio button to choose a Wan load balancing feature the smart link backup feature ensures continuous Wan connectivity on the router in this mode a backup W Port will take over if the primary one fails if you want to use this feature choose the desired primary Wan Port from the drop- down list the load balance option uses both Wan connections at the same time this option increases the available bandwidth of the router click save to save the settings to edit the Dual van settings of a port click the configuration button in the WAN bandwidth area enter the maximum upload and download bandwidth in kilobits per second check with your internet service provider for more information in the network service detection area check the enable network service detection check boox if you want the router to Ping a specific specific IP address to test for w connectivity in the retry count field enter the number of times the router pings the specific IP address the default value is five enter the time in seconds the router will wait between pings in the retry time Outfield the default time is 30 seconds choose an action to take when a ping test fails from the when fail drop-down list the keep system log and remove the connection option gives Wan control to the backup interface the primary Wan connection takes control back once a connection is reestablished the generate the error condition in the system log option records an error in the connection into the system log but does not move traffic to the backup when interface next configure the IP settings of the location that the router will ping to tester internet connectivity check the default gateway box to Ping the configured default gateway check the ISP host check box and enter the IP address of the ISP server in the field to Ping the ISP server the router is connected to check the remote host checkbox and enter an IP address in the field to Ping a remote host check the DNS lookup host checkbox and enter a domain or host name for the router to Ping any combination of these options can be used next configure the protocol binding area protocol binding is a feature that is used to send specific traffic through a specific Wan interface the purpose of this feature is to prioritize two or more types of traffic to optimize Network efficiency this feature is only available if the Dual Wan mode is configured as a load balance from the service dropdown list choose the type of traffic that will be used for protocol binding enter the source IP addresses that applies to the selected traffic in the source IP field enter the destination IP address that applies to the protocol binding in the destination IP field to enter a range of IP addresses enter the first address in the first field and add the last address in the last field to enter a single address enter the same address in both Fields choose the WAN interface you want the traffic to go through in the interface drop-down list check the enable check boox to enable the traffic rule finally click add to list to add the rule to the table to edit a protocol binding entry select the entry from the table and change the fields above the table once finished click update to delete a protocol binding rule select the entry to delete from the table table and click delete at the bottom of the table to add a service that is not included in the service dropdown list click the service management button enter a name for the service in the service name field choose the protocol that the service uses from the protocol drop- down list TCP forwards all transmission control protocol packets UDP forwards all user datagram protocol packets and ipv 6 forwards all Internet Protocol version 6 traffic if the protocol is TCP or UDP enter the ports reserved for the service in the port range Fields click add to list the entry is now available in the service drop-down list click save to save all configurations thank you for watching and for more video tutorials please visit the Cisco YouTube channel know

title: Cisco Small Business FindIT | Simple Network Equipment Installation
description:
The Cisco FindIT Network Discovery Utility that uses the Cisco Automated Software Delivery Service to provide easy speedy access to Small Business firmware.

Subscribe to Cisco's YouTube channel: http://cs.co/Subscribe.
transcript: Hello everybody. My name is David Harper. I'm the product manager for the Cisco Find it network discovery utility. And over the next couple of minutes, I just want to show you how you can use Cisco Find it when installing new network equipment. Uh for the benefit of people who may not be familiar with Cisco Find it, it is a plugin for the web browser. You can see here we get this toolbar with um a few links here. If we click on the find it button here, we open up a sidebar and you can see I've got a network here with router, couple of switches, couple of wireless access points. Okay. And an analog telephone adapter. Okay. So, this is a brand new network. I've taken all the equipment out of the box, plugged it all together, and um what I can see here is find it has discovered everything in the network. It if I mouse over the device, I get a tool tip showing me information about the devices. So, what type of device it is, what firmware version it's running, what its MAC address is. If I um am having a problem and I need to log a case with the support center, I'll often get asked for the serial number. I can see the serial number directly from here. But uh probably more immediately useful is I can see what the IP address is. Okay. So I can uh double click on a device here and go straight to the web gooey and be able to log onto it without having to go and check DHCP tables and you know without having to log onto the router and look through the DHCP tables. Now the other thing that I can see here if I have a look is I've got these icons next to a couple of devices and what they're telling me is that there is a later firmware version available on cisco.com for these devices. Okay. So if I uh click on one of these devices now uh what find it will do is it goes away to cisco.com. It says there's a later version of firmware here. I accept the end user license agreement and it starts downloading that firmware to my PC. If I mouse over the device, I'll just accept that. If I mouse over the device, it'll tell me what that later firmware version is and what my current firmware version is. In this case, it's 1.062. The latest version available is 1.074. So, I've clicked on um the icon to start downloading. And you can see that that file is now downloading in the background. Uh now this wireless access point, the firmware downloaded rather quickly because I actually had downloaded before. If I click here, it opens up a folder. It shows me where the firmware is. And because that file was already present in this directory, what find it did was it just validated the check sum to make sure the file hadn't been corrupted. And since it was all in good shape, it um completed the transfer immediately. Now, what I can do is I'll just uh open up the access point, log into it quickly. Now that I've got that firmware, I haven't had to hunt through cisco.com to find the right firmware for the right device. Um I can just very easily grab that um update and apply it to the device. Okay. Now, while that upgrade's happening, if I go back to my switch, I can go in here. I can start doing configuration changes. Maybe in in this case, I'll just change the host name. Something simple. And when I apply that, you'll see in a moment that that host name change will take effect. See that switch now has the host name that I've configured. You can also see here where that access point that I'm upgrading, the entry here has gone red. That's because the access point has dropped off the network. Sometimes if you have a lot of devices in the sidebar and something drops off the network, you know, previously it was a little bit hard to see that there was something missing or that there was a problem. Now it's very obvious it's dropped off the network. If I mouse over it, I can see that um it's no longer on the network. It was last seen 38 seconds ago. So that gives me an idea of just how long it's been gone. Now when uh the upgrade finishes, which will take a couple of minutes, but when that upgrade finishes, that um entry will go back to black, you know, when the device is seen on the network, and I'll be able to see the new version has taken effect. Now, the other things I can do here, maybe if I'm having problems setting something up or I don't quite know uh what to do next, if I go into the support menu here, I can um find out how to get in touch with the support center, here's all the phone numbers for the support center if I need to log a case or possibly I just want to go to the support community where I can hunt through the knowledge bases there and find more information about specific products or uh you know, problems that other people have had in the past and what the solution was. So, I can go there. Finally, if um you know, I don't want to speak to somebody, but I I I would like to talk to a live person, I can always uh go to the online chat um and have a chat session with a um uh support center engineer. Okay. Uh so, that's about it. I'm just there's just a couple of quick things that you can use Cisco Find It for to help you uh when you're installing a network. It just makes the process go a little more smoothly and um hopefully saves you a bit of time and a little bit of um effort.

title: Cisco Tech Talk: Small Business Quick VPN Installation Tips
description:
How to implement Quick VPN has always been a popular question.  This video will show you installation tips on Quick VPN.

Learn more: http://cs.co/jlbYTvpn.

Subscribe to Cisco's YouTube channel: http://cs.co/Subscribe.
transcript: [Music] hi I'm Ruben Lopez from Cisco today we're going to talk about Cisco quick VPN installation tips for the Windows operating system and some requirements to properly run quick [Music] VPN with a widespread use of mobile technology and an increased reliability of Wireless networks more and more businesses are turning towards virtual private networks or vpns so that off-site employees can securely connect the workplace from [Music] anywhere a VPN is a Communications tunnel between a remote worker's computer and your network encryption and authentication features prevent unauthorized entry and keep communication secure this do diagram illustrates the difference between using an unencrypted connection and using a VPN secured connection on a public unrusted network such as the wi-fi at your average coffee shop the secure tunnel encrypts your internet traffic which helps prevent people from trying to capture your passwords and other sensitive data Cisco quick VPN provides an easy costeffective way set up a VPN all you have to do is install the free software on your computer and configure a few simple settings on the router since quick VPN clients will be connected to the router using the secure socket layer protocol or SSL you'll need to enable Remote Management for Port 443 on your device to do this log in your router's Configuration utility and find the firewall settings section keep in mind that the navigation for each router may be slightly different next find the subsection that allows you to enable Remote Management it is commonly labeled as general or basic settings depending on your router then check the enable check boox for Remote Management and in the Remote Management Port field set the port number to 4 Port 3 and then click save the next requirement is create user accounts for your clients so that they can connect to the VPN to do this find the VPN section and then find the subsection that allows you to add VPN users or clients it is commonly labeled as VPN clients or VPN users depending on your router then in the VPN client table click add row this allows you to enter a username and password for the new client enter the desired username and password and then select quick VPN from the protocol drop-down list and then click save first you need to turn on Windows Firewall for public networks to do this click the start button and go to the control [Music] panel then select Windows fire wall from the control panel items if your firewall for public networks isn't on go to turn Windows firewall on or off then under the public network location settings go ahead and turn on Windows Firewall and then click [Music] okay next you need to add an inbound rule to allow icmp package Transmissions to do this go to advance settings on the Windows Firewall page then click on inbound rules and then over to the right click new rule this opens the new inbound rule wizard page click custom to create a custom Rule and then click next go ahead and let the rule apply for all programs and click next on the next step open the protocol type dropdown list and select icmp V4 and then click next for the next three steps the defaults are okay so go ahead and click next until you get to the name step here you can specify a name for the rule just for your own reference and then click finish the last requirement is to have the IP SEC service running to do this click the start button and search for Ms config using the search program and files field click on the MS config program and the system configuration window will open then click on the services Tab and scroll down until you find IP secc policy agent ensure that the IP SEC policy agent service is checked and then click okay that concludes our requirements for Cisco quick VPN for more information refer to the link in the description I'm Ruben Lopez and thanks for watching [Music]

title: RV320 & RV325 USB 3G 4G Modem Configuration
description:
An easy how to video on setting up a an RV320 and RV325 with a 3G/4G modem

Subscribe to Cisco's YouTube channel: http://cs.co/Subscribe.
transcript: hello and welcome to Cisco small business video on demand I'm going to demonstrate how to configure the 3G 4G modem on an RV 320 Cisco's small business RV series routers are easy to configure providing security growth and collaboration to your business first you'll need to log into your router and then go to setup under the network settings scroll down and click USB 1 and then click Edit then you'll need to enter the information provided by your service provider some service providers require that you enter a pin code that's associated with your SIM card the access point name is the internet network that your mobile device is connecting to and to the access point name provided by your mobile network service provider for this demonstration my provider only requires a dialing number username and password you will also want to enable the NS enter your service providers DNS server or enter your preferred public dns server then click Save to save your settings next you will need to plug in your USB modem into USB port 1 then go to your network settings scroll down check USB 1 and then edit you should see an indication that the modem is connected if you click on USB failover settings you'll be able to see the signal that the modem is receiving by default the operation mode is in primary mode you have two other options failover hot standby or failover cold standby primary mode is used when a 3G 4G link is your primary when connection failover hot standby is used when the LAN Ethernet port loses connection all traffic will then be routed to the USB modem hot standby means that the USB modem will be powered on while it is in standby mode cold standby means that the USB modem will be powered off while it is in standby mode first I'm going to select the primary mode and test for internet access now I've confirmed that my USB modem is working correctly next I'm going to demonstrate the failover hot standby mode I'm going to plug in my Ethernet LAN to my ISP modem and then change my USB failover settings to failover hot standby mode next I'm going to demonstrate what happens when the Ethernet LAN interface gets disconnected I'm going to open my browser and go to a website that tells me what my public IP address is then I'm going to open up the command prompt and do a continuous ping to a public address and then disconnect the LAN interface now I'm going to disconnect the Ethernet LAN port you and now it is successfully failed over to the 3G 4G modem next I just want to verify that my outgoing public IP address has changed and looks like we're good when the Ethernet LAN connection is re-established it will automatically route all Internet traffic back to the LAN interface that concludes this demonstration of how to configure a 3G 4G modem on an RV 320 router here's a list of more Cisco small business devices that may also suit your business needs for more information go to WWE my cool assistance please call one eight six six six zero six one eight six six thank you for choosing cisco small business and i'd like to thank you for watching you

series routers are easy to configure giving you security adding growth and collaboration to your business after you log into the router click on setup under the network settings you'll have the option to change your subnet or change your when IP address by default the W is set to obtain an IP automatically here you can change your options to match your ISP settings the rv300 series come with dual USB ports that support 3G 4G modems or flash drives here is where you can configure your modem settings you may also use a USB failover settings this will provide you redundancy in case of Wan failure if you prefer to change your host name you may do it here I'm going to use rv320 and if you do not have a domain name you may leave this section blank if you need to change your DHCP scope click on DHCP then change your device IP address for this demonstration I'm going to use 172.16.0.0 do1 16.5 do10 through do30 next you have option for your DNS server for this demonstration I'm going to use DNS as below then enter your preferred DNS server down below you also have tftp server options for voice over IP after you click save you'll be prompted to change your IP address click yes after the router reboots you will then obtain a new IP address if you have the Cisco find it tool installed in your browser you can use it to discover and open the login page or you can type in the IP address in your browser after you log into the router click on system management then click on diagnostic here is where you can test connectivity to the internet or your local network next click on firmware upgrade from here you can upgrade to the latest firmware using your PC or from a USB drive connected to one of the USB ports on the RV 320 if you click on backup and restore here is will you perform a backup of your configuration before you do an upgrade next click on port management then click on VLAN membership here is where you can add multiple VLAN IDs the rv320 only supports up to seven vlans next click on firewall here's where you enable Remote Management and the sslvpn click on save to save your settings you will then be prompted on how to log in remotely next click on access rules this is where you can allow or deny specific IP addresses or ports to your network next click on content filter this is where you can deny access to specific websites or by blocking keyword searches next click on VPN then click on Gateway to Gateway this is where you can set up a sight to site ipvpn tunnel between multiple offices the RV 320 allows up to 25 s to site VPN tunnels next click on client to Gateway this is where you can set up up to to 25 ipvpn clients the rv300 series routers do not support quick VPN next click on sslvpn then click on group management this is where you can create groups and assign users to those groups next click on advaned setting here you can change your sslvpn service port to 443 10443 or 20 443 next click on user management this is where you can add users and assign them to a specific group Next click on Wizard here you can launch the basic Setup Wizard or the access rule Setup Wizard to assist you with your configuration that concludes this demonstration of how to configure an rv300 series router here is a list of more Cisco small business devices that may also suit your business business needs for more information visit www.cisco.com or if you need technical support call 1-866 6061 1866 thank you for choosing Cisco small business and I'd like to thank you for watching [Music]

title: Configuring Auto Voice Vlan with QoS on the SG500 Series Switch
description:
How to video on Configuring Auto Voice Vlan with QoS on the SG500 Series Switch

Subscribe to Cisco's YouTube channel: http://cs.co/Subscribe.
transcript: Welcome to Cisco Small Business video on demand series. Today, an SG 500X series switch is getting a voice VLAN configuration with quality of service set, six ports for phones and data, a beefy 10 gig uplink port to connect to a core or distribution layer, passing both voice and data, bonus, a port configured for our lobby phone only. All this in under three minutes. Let's get started. My PC is connected to port 7 on the switch and I have statically assigned my address 192.1681.10. The switch is at its default IP address of 192.1681.254 and is pingable. I put the address into the web browser to connect to the switch. I have upgraded the firmware on the switch and changed the default password. But other than that, the switch is at default configuration. I will be working on a powerful but simple to configure SG500X48 port PoE switch. The firmware that I'm using is right there. We look at the default configuration. We see a default of VLAN one. It is the only VLAN that is configured on the switch. Checking our port VLAN membership, we see that all the ports are in a trunk state with VLAN one as untagged traffic. Over on our voice VLAN properties page, we set our voice VLAN to be 100 and our quality of service settings are here. All values available and we will accept the default values. A message appears letting us know that we will be advertising our voice VLAN, which is what we want. We have success. Over on the VLAN settings page, we see VLAN 100 has been statically created, but is in a disabled state. I have devices connected to ports, but there is VLAN 100 is not applied to any ports yet. Going to our portto VLAN page, we change our VLAN to 100 and click go to bring up the state of VLAN 100 on ports. We see it's all excluded. On the six ports that we are connecting our phones to, we tag VLAN 100. On our lobby phone, which is port 10, we will untag VLAN 100. And on our uplink port, we will tag it. Hit apply. And we have success. Again, checking the port VLAN membership page, we see that our six phones have VLAN 100 tagged. Our lobby phone was untagged and our uplink port is tagged for VLAN 100. Finally, we need to go over to the interface settings page and change the lobby phone port from a trunk to an access port, giving a basic level of security, only allowing a device connected to the port access the VLAN 100. Change it to access and click apply. And we are done. Six phones with PCs, one lobby phone, an uplink port configured, all with quality of service applied. Stop that timer. under 3 minutes. It's that easy. We see 100 is now enabled with the devices connected to those ports. Thank you for watching.

to separate your physical land traffic into multiple virtual partitions this is useful if you want to move a computer to a different physical location and still remain on the same VLAN first log into the web Configuration utility and then choose VLAN management VLAN settings in the VLAN settings page click the add button in the resulting window you have two ways to create a VLAN you can either create a single VLAN by clicking on the VLAN radio button or you can create a range of vlans by clicking on the Range radio button if you create a single VLAN enter the VLAN ID and name for the VLAN you may also specify here if you want to enable the vlan's interface State note that the interface state will remain down until a physical device is connected to the port the VLAN is assigned to check the enabled checkbox under link status SNM traps if you want to generate SNMP traps whenever the port link status has been changed click apply to save your configuration if you want to add additional vlans click on the add button to add more vlans if you wish to create a ranger vlans enter the starting range for your VLAN ID and the upper range in the text field to the right click apply to save your configuration once you have finished creating your vlans it is recommended to go to the copy save configuration page to save your running configuration to the Startup configuration so your changes will be saved upon next reboot now you will need to assign the ports you wish to the appropriate VLAN on the web Configuration utility choose VLAN Management Port to VLAN on the port to VLAN page locate the first drop- down menu next to the VLAN ID equals to field and choose your appropriate VLAN locate the next drop- down menu to the right next to the interface type equals to field and choose either port or lag for reference a port is a physical entity that is used for connections on the series switches and Link aggregation or lag is a method of using two ethernet ports in parallel title: How to Set Up Chain and Ring Topologies in Networking: Step-by-Step Guide
description:
In this video, we walk you through the process of setting up Chain and Ring topologies in a network environment. Learn the key differences between these two network topologies, including their benefits and drawbacks. We provide a step-by-step guide to configuring each topology, covering best practices for ensuring optimal network performance, reliability, and scalability. Whether you're designing a small office network or planning a large enterprise infrastructure, understanding how to set up Chain and Ring topologies is crucial for network architects and engineers.
  
  Related links:
  Cisco Network Topologies Overview → https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/automation/network-topology.html#:~:text=Network%20topology%20is%20used%20to,well%20as%20how%20data%20flows.?dtid=osclytb001771
  Cisco Routing and Switching Solutions → https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/switches/solution-listing.html?dtid=osclytb001771
  
  What you’ll learn in this video:
  – How to configure Chain and Ring topologies in a network setup
  – The differences between Chain and Ring topologies and their advantages
  – How to ensure network redundancy and performance using these topologies
  – Step-by-step configuration for both Chain and Ring network topologies
  
  This video is ideal for network engineers, IT professionals, and system administrators looking to enhance their understanding of network topology design and configuration.

transcript: [Music] hello and welcome to this episode of stocking Solutions labs and Demos in this video we'll go over how to configure chain and ring topologies on the sg550 XG and sg350 XG stackable switches please note however that the sg550 XG and sg350 XG cannot be linked in the same stack for all device is shown in this video we'll be using software version 2.1.0 46 let's get started [Music] a chain topology is a linear connection between all units via stacking links starting with one switch each unit connects to its neighboring switch through a single cable between their stack ports until the last unit has been linked with the one before it if a link between the two units fails the switch stack will be cut off where the fail occurs for this reason a chain topology is not very robust as it does not have full redundancy this is where ring topologies have an advantage in a ring topology all units in the stack are connected in a loop with the last unit connecting back to the first by connecting them in this way you provide additional redundancy in the case of a failed stack link as seen here the failure of one Link in a ring topology causes the stack to revert to a chain topology and maintains the Stack's functionality thus a ring topology is more reliable than a chain topology and allows for more stable stack operation let's show you how to physically set up each topology for this demonstration we'll be using four sg550 XG switches in a chain topology keep in mind that you can use any network port on the switch as a stack Port let's start by taking a cable and connecting the first and second switch together take note of the ports you connect to on each switch you'll need this information when designating stock ports lat here then take another cable and connect the second and third switch together repeat this process for every switch you want to include in your stack a ring topology uses the same configuration as a chain except the last unit connects back to the first therefore in order to make the stack a ring topology we just connect the last switch back to the first one now that we have physically established a ring topology we'll go over their configurations in the graphical user interface this is where we designate the appropriate ports for each unit that will be used to stack [Music] for each switch you'll need to log into the web Configuration utility to configure the stock ports start by logging into the first switch at the top of your stack and then click on Administration and then stack management the stack management page shows your current stock topology and designates which switch in your stack is the stack Master additionally it provides a visual stack topology view of your current stack since your stack ports haven't been configured yet each switch is designated as a the master of its own single unit chain topology under the unit View and stack Port configuration section you can simply click on the ports you want to designate as stacking ports for the switch these should be the same ports you use to connect your switches earlier note that in order to enable stacking at least two stacking ports must be selected in the graphically user interface by default there are no preconfigured stack ports on the switch you can designate two to four stacking ports in the SG 350 XG and two eight stacking ports on the sg550 XG in the unit ID after reset drop-down list choose Auto in order to automatically assign each stack member a unique unit ID the assignment process will be based on each unit's Mac address and determine the initial Master backup and slave units finally click apply and reboot to save your changes a confirmation window will open asking if you would like to continue click okay and your device will reboot now we simply need to configure the stock ports for the other three switches using the same procedure log into each switch's web Configuration utility navigate to Administration and then stock management and designate the appropriate ports we are using in the physical setup after the changes have been applied and all switches have finished rebooting the 4 unit stack will be established once we log into our stack master and navigate to Administration and stack management we can view new updated information on the stack under stack topology view all four units of the current ring topology appear and we can select each individual switch for stack configuration clicking on individual unit will show you which of its stacking ports are active and whether the unit is a master backup or slave within the topology a brief overview of your stack configuration can also be found in your master switches system summary if you click on status and statistics then system summary you can view the units in your stack as well as individual switch serial numbers and pvid numbers the sg350 XG and sg550 XG switches support stacking under two types of topologies ring and chain a ring topology is more favorable than a chain topology due to its additional redundancy however both topologies can be used to establish a functional stack to configure each topology you need to physically link ports between each switch and then designate those ports as stack ports in the graphical user interface this concludes our tutorial on ring and chain topologies for more information please please see the article below or check out the Cisco small business support Community for further assistance I'm Remy from Cisco and thanks for watching this episode of stacking Solutions labs and demos [Music]

title: What Is Stacking in Networking? Benefits and Configurations Explained
description:
In this video, we explain the concept of ""stacking"" in networking, a configuration method that allows multiple physical network switches to operate as a single logical unit. Learn how stacking improves scalability, simplifies management, and enhances redundancy. We will also cover the different types of stacking methods, including hardware and software-based solutions, and how they benefit modern network infrastructures. Discover how stacking increases network efficiency and performance, helping businesses meet their growing connectivity needs.
  
  Related links:
  Cisco Switch Stacking Overview → https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/smb/switches/cisco-350x-series-stackable-managed-switches/smb5252-what-is-stacking.html?dtid=osclytb001771
  Cisco Catalyst Switches → https://www.cisco.com/site/us/en/products/networking/switches/catalyst-9000-switches/index.html?dtid=osclytb001771
  
  What you’ll learn in this video:
  – The concept and benefits of network switch stacking
  – How stacking improves scalability and network performance
  – The differences between hardware and software-based stacking
  – Best practices for configuring stacked switches in a network
  
  This video is ideal for network engineers, IT professionals, and system administrators who want to understand how stacking works and how it can be implemented in their network infrastructure.

  #CiscoStacking #NetworkStacking #NetworkPerformance #Scalability #NetworkingSolutions #CiscoSwitches #ITProfessionals #NetworkRedundancy #TechInnovation #NetworkingBestPractices"
transcript:
STACKING IS A FEATURE AVAILABLE ON SELECT
CISCO SMALL BUSINESS SWITCHES. TO UNDERSTAND THIS FEATURE AND ITS BENEFITS, LET'S TAKE A LOOK AT SOME BASIC STACKING CONCEPTS AND TERMS. FIRST, LET'S DEFINE WHAT A STACK IS. A STACK IS A NETWORK SOLUTION COMPOSED OF TWO OR MORE STACKABLE SWITCHES. SWITCHES THAT ARE PART OF A STACK BEHAVE AS ONE SINGLE DEVICE. AS A RESULT, A STACKING SOLUTION SHOWS THE CHARACTERISTICS AND FUNCTIONALITY OF A SINGLE SWITCH, WHILE HAVING AN INCREASED NUMBER OF PORTS. THIS ALLOWS USERS TO EXPAND THEIR NETWORK CAPACITY WITHOUT THE HASSLE OF MANAGING MULTIPLE DEVICES. ADDITIONALLY, SWITCHES CAN BE ADDED OR REMOVED FROM A STACK AS NEEDED WITHOUT AFFECTING THE OVERALL OPERATION OF THE STACK. DEPENDING ON ITS TOPOLOGY, A STACK CAN CONTINUE TO TRANSFER DATA EVEN IF A LINK OR UNIT WITHIN THE STACK FAILS. THIS MAKES STACKING AN EFFECTIVE, FLEXIBLE, AND SCALABLE SOLUTION TO EXPAND NETWORK CAPACITY. NOW THAT WE HAVE A GENERAL UNDERSTANDING OF WHAT A STACK IS AND WHY YOU WOULD WANT TO CONSIDER A STACK FOR YOUR NETWORK, LET'S GO OVER SOME BASIC STACKNG TERMS THAT YOU SHOULD KNOW BEFORE SETTING ONE UP. FIRST, A STACK HAS A MASTER, OR COMMANDER. THE MASTER IS A SWITCH IN THE STACK THAT HANDLES THE CONFIGURATION FOR THE ENTIRE STACK. WHEN YOU WANT TO MANAGE YOUR STACK, THE MASTER UNIT IS THE DEVICE THAT YOU CONNECT TO IN ORDER TO MAKE CHANGES. THE MASTER ALSO HANDLES OTHER IMPORTANT STACK FUNCTIONS SUCH AS, DETECTING WHEN SWITCHES ENTER OR LEAVE THE STACK, AND UPGRADING OUTDATED SWITCHES. THE BACKUP IS A SWITCH THAT WILL BECOME THE NEW MASTER IF THE ORIGINAL MASTER GOES OFFLINE. IN THIS WAY, A BACKUP HELPS MAINTAIN THE RESILIENCY OF THE STACK. A SLAVE, OR MEMBER, SERVES AS AN ADDITIONAL UNIT WITHIN THE STACK. UNLIKE THE MASTER AND THE BACKUP UNITS, THE SLAVE DOES NOT SERVE AN ADDITIONAL FUNCTION WITHIN THE STACK OTHER THAN TO INCREASE PORT CAPACITY. AS A RESULT, IF THE MASTER AND BACKUP UNITS FAIL, THE STACK WILL BECOME DISABLED. FINALLY,
A STACK PORT IS A PORT ON THE SWITCH THAT IS USED TO COMMUNICATE WITH OTHER SWITCHES IN THE STACK. DEPENDING ON THE MODEL, A SWITCH CAN HAVE EITHER PRECONFIGURED OR USER-DEFINED STACK PORTS. NOW THAT WE'VE GONE OVER THESE BASIC STACKING CONCEPTS AND TERMS, YOU'VE HOPEFULLY GAINED A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF WHAT A STACK IS AND HOW ONE WOULD FIT IN TO YOUR NETWORK. FOR MORE INFORMATION ABOUT STACKING, CLICK ON THE ARTICLE BELOW OR VISIT THE CISCO SMALL BUSINESS SUPPORT COMMUNITY FOR FURTHER ASSISTANCE. THANKS FOR WATCHING!

title: Master Backup: SG550XG and SG350XG Switches
description:
Learn about stack unit failures and resulting master backup processes on the SG550XG and SG350XG switches.

Subscribe to Cisco's YouTube channel: http://cs.co/Subscribe.
transcript:
HELLO, AND WELCOME TO THIS EPISODE OF STACKING SOLUTIONS, LABS, AND DEMOS.
TODAY, WE'LL BE GOING OVER MASTER BACKUP ON THE SG550XG
AND SG350XG SERIES MANAGED SWITCHES.   FOR A STACK TO OPERATE, IT MUST HAVE A MASTER UNIT.
THIS SWITCH HANDLES THE CONFIGURATION OF THE ENTIRE STACK.
IF THE MASTER UNIT SHOULD FAIL, ANOTHER UNIT MUST BE AVAILABLE TO SERVE AS
THE NEW STACK MASTER. THIS UNIT IS CALLED THE MASTER BACKUP.
IN THIS VIDEO, WE WILL GO OVER STACK UNIT FAILURES
AND THE RESULTING MASTER BACK UP PROCESSES. LET'S GET STARTED! WHEN SETTING UP A STACK OF FOUR SG550XG SWITCHES IN A RING TOPOLOGY,
WE CAN SEE THAT UNIT 1 IS THE MASTER UNIT WITHIN THE STACK,
UNIT 2 IS THE MASTER BACKUP, AND UNITS 3 AND 4 ARE THE SLAVE UNITS.
IF ONE OF THE LINKS TO THE MASTER UNIT FAILS, THE UNIT WILL STILL SERVE AS THE STACK MASTER;
HOWEVER, THE STACK WILL REVERT TO A CHAIN TOPOLOGY.
IF THE MASTER UNIT IS DISCONNECTED FROM THE STACK AT ALL POINTS,
THE NEW STACK WILL CONTAIN ONLY UNITS 2, 3, AND 4,
WITH UNIT 2 ASSUMING THE NEW MASTER ROLE.   THIS IS CALLED A SWITCHOVER, WHERE THE BACKUP UNIT TAKES OVER THE MASTER
ROLE AND MAINTAINS THE OPERATION OF THE STACK.
IN ORDER FOR THE BACKUP TO BECOME THE MASTER, BOTH UNITS MUST MAINTAIN A WARM STANDBY AT
ALL TIMES. IN A WARM STANDBY, BOTH THE MASTER
AND ITS BACKUP UNITS ARE SYNCHRONIZED WITH THE STATIC CONFIGURATION.
WHEN THE BACKUP UNIT BECOMES THE MASTER, ALL OF ITS PROCESSES AND STACK PROTOCOLS ARE
INITIALIZED TO TAKE RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE ENTIRE STACK.
AS A RESULT, THERE IS TEMPORARILY NO TRAFFIC FORWARDED TO THIS UNIT. WHEN THE BACKUP UNIT BECOMES THE MASTER, THE INITIAL SLAVE UNITS REMAIN ACTIVE
AND CONTINUE TO FORWARD PACKETS BASED ON THE CONFIGURATION
FROM THE ORIGINAL MASTER. THIS MINIMIZES DATA TRAFFIC INTERRUPTION.
ONCE THE BACKUP UNIT HAS COMPLETED THE TRANSITION TO THE MASTER STATE,
IT INDIVIDUALLY RESETS THE DEFAULT CONFIGURATION FOR EACH SLAVE.
THIS HELPS PREVENT CONFIGURATION ERRORS DURING THE SWITCHOVER. IF THE ORIGINAL MASTER UNIT IS RECONNECTED AFTER THE SWITCHOVER,
THE NEW MASTER, OR ORIGINAL BACKUP UNIT, REBOOTS AND BECOMES THE BACKUP ONCE AGAIN,
WHILE THE ORIGINAL MASTER UNIT ASSUMES THE MASTER ROLE. THE MASTER BACKUP PROCESS IS AN EFFICIENT WAY FOR A STACK TO CONTINUE TO FUNCTION NORMALLY IN THE EVENT OF A UNIT OR LINK FAILURE.
IF THE MASTER UNIT FAILS, THE BACKUP UNIT ASSUMES THE MASTER ROLE
AND CONTINUES TO FUNCTION AS THE MASTER. THIS SWITCHOVER PREVENTS THE FAILURE OF THE
MASTER FROM CAUSING THE ENTIRE STACK TO FAIL. THIS CONCLUDES OUR TUTORIAL ON MASTER BACKUP FOR THE SG550XG AND THE SG350XG SWITCHES.
FOR MORE INFORMATION, PLEASE CHECK OUT THE CISCO SMALL BUSINESS SUPPORT COMMUNITY
FOR ASSISTANCE. I'M LEESA FROM CISCO AND THANKS FOR WATCHING
THIS EPISODE OF STACKING SOLUTIONS, LABS, AND DEMOS.

title: Fast Link Failover: SG550XG, SG350XG Switches
description:
See an overview on fast link failover, a stacking feature that reduces the duration of data packet loss on these Cisco switches.

Subscribe to Cisco's YouTube channel: http://cs.co/Subscribe.
transcript:
Hello, and welcome to this
episode of Stacking Solutions, Labs and Demos. Today, we'll be going over fast link failover
on the SG550XG and the SG350XG series managed switches. Fast link failover is a process
designed to reduce the duration of data packet loss in case a link in a stack port fails.
This process is only supported in a ring topology because, in this set up, the stack can still
remain operational even if a link fails. Suppose we have four units
in a stack that are set up in a ring topology, where unit one can send traffic to unit two
or unit four. If unit one is supposed to send traffic to unit three, the traffic can be
routed in two ways: unit one to unit two to unit three, or unit one to unit four to unit
three. Therefore, if the link between units one and two fails, unit one can send traffic
to unit three via unit four, and vice versa. Until the stack topology is
recovered, the stack unit sends back the packets that are supposed to be sent through the failed
stack port, transmitting the packets through the connected stack port all the way to the
designated unit. Fast Link Failover is a feature
that helps minimize data packet loss when a link in a stack port fails. This concludes
our tutorial on fast link failover for the SG550XG and the SG350XG switches. For more
information and assistance, check out the Cisco Small Business support community. I'm Leesa from Cisco and thanks
for watching this episode of Stacking Solutions, Labs, and Demos.

title: Auto-Image Update: SG550XG, SG350XG Switches
description: See a demonstration of the auto-image update stacking feature available on Cisco small business SG350XG and SG550XG series switches.
transcript:
Hello, and welcome to this episode of stacking
solutions, labs, and demos. Today we'll be going over the auto-image update
feature available on the SG350XG and SG550XG series managed switches. Any switch in a stack must have the same firmware
image as the master in order for the stack to remain operational. With auto-image update, the stack can change
the firmware of any newly inserted device to keep it working with the rest of the stack. This is done by referring to the stack master's
currently installed image, and comparing it to the new device. If the firmwares don't match, the image from
the master is copied over to the new switch and saved. For this tutorial, we'll be using a stack
of SG550XG switches. Please note, however, that auto-image update
also works with a stack of SG350XG switches. To demonstrate this process, we will insert
a switch into a stack, designate the appropriate stack ports, and reboot the switch in order
for the changes to take place. Upon reboot, the software version check will
be performed. If differences in software versions are detected,
the auto-image update process will begin. When this process is initiated, notifications
will appear on the right side of the screen. Once the image transfer is completed, the
switch will reboot. Upon reboot, the device will be listed in
the new stack, along with its updated software version number. The auto-image update feature provides a simple
and automated process for keeping all switches in a stack up to date. For more information, go to cisco.com or check
out the Cisco small business support community for assistance. I'm Remy from Cisco, and thanks for watching
this episode of stacking solutions, labs, and demos.

title: Cisco FindIT Network Management | Small Business Network Monitoring
description: Check out the Cisco FindIT platform that helps IT administrators monitor and manage networks, saving time, energy, and money. Deploy, configure and monitor networks built on Cisco switches, routers and wireless access points.
transcript:
As small businesses become more reliant on
digital technology to run their business, the network is becoming an extremely critical
part of their operations. Of course all of this "digitalization" puts
more demand on the IT admins and integrators who manage these systems. Life for them can seem like one big fire drill. This is where Cisco FindIT Network Management
comes in. Cisco's FindIT Network Management gives IT
professionals an affordable way to deploy, configure, and monitor networks built on Cisco
100 through 500 series switches, routers, and wireless access points. Most of the solutions available today either
only manage a single type of device, such as a router, or allow users to do basic monitoring
of a set of individual devices. FindIT Network Management is designed to manage
the network as a single system, reducing the amount of time needed to maintain the network
and increasing the system uptime. How does it work? Cisco FindIT Network Management is composed
of two applications - the probe and the manager. The probe resides on the local network - one
probe per site. The manager can reside anywhere as long as
the probes can communicate with it. For networks with only a single site, the
manager is optional. When first deployed, the probe will discover
all of the network, including the PC's, servers and mobile devices connected to the network. By getting port information from the switches
and access points, FindIT is able to build a topology map showing how things are connected. You can connect to the probe's intuitive user
interface and see the network topology map, along with a list of networking devices, including
their firmware versions, serial numbers, and other important information. Floor plans can be added to show the physical
locations of the networking equipment. Once installed the FindIT probe will send
alert messages and track network utilization, number of clients on the network, and other
key statistics. From the FindIT probe user interface, the
user can also shut down ports, add new VLANs or wireless networks, and make other changes
to the network. You can also back up the configuration files
or install new firmware on every Cisco small business device on the network with a few
clicks! If there are mutliple sites being managed,
the FindIT Manager will be the dashboard to see any critical alerts for any of the probes
and be able to quickly get access to the selected site. The manager can also generate reports that
can be used in planning discussions with the business owner. With FindIT Network Management, IT professionals
can gain some sanity back in their lives. Being able to operate more efficiently, maintain
higher network uptime and proactively address potential problems, will make the IT professional's
life easier, and the end-user happier. Please check out our other videos to learn
more about FindIT Network Management. You can also go to www.cisco.com/go/findit
for more detailed information on cisco's FindIT Network Management. I'm Remy from Cisco, and thanks for watching!

Modems for additional failover, and specific LTE usage. The RV325 can also be rack mounted. These Cisco VPN routers are business proven. They offer solid performance, secure VPN technology,

best support. I'm Remy from Cisco, and thanks for watching.

title: Cisco AnyConnect for the RV340/RV345/RV345P
description: See how to configure and connect to your VPN using Cisco AnyConnect Secure Mobility Client on the RV340, RV345, and RV345P.
transcript:
Hi, I'm Keshav from Cisco. Today we'll be going over how to configure
and connect with AnyConnect on the new RV340 and RV345 series routers. We'll start by going over how to download
Cisco's AnyConnect VPN client and then discuss the SSL VPN configuration associated with
the RV340 and RV345. First, download the Cisco AnyConnnect VPN
client from the Cisco AnyConnect website. Next, run the installer to install the VPN
client. Connect to and log in to your device. From the homepage, click VPN, then SSL VPN. Under the General Configuration tab, you can
configure both mandatory and optional gateway settings that relate to your SSL VPN server. Then, under the Group Policies tab, click
Add, Edit, or Delete to edit basic VPN information such as names, DNS settings, and WINS settings. For both of these tabs, click Apply to apply
your changes. An example configuration would be as follows:
go to the VPN tab and click the SSL VPN. Under the General Configuration tab, click
the On bubble next to "Cisco SSL VPN Server." Next, leave all fields default, but set the
Client Address Pool field to the IP address of the desired pool. This address pool should be preferably different
than any LAN DHCP ranges in your network. You may also wish to change the client domain
and what's displayed on the login banner. click Apply when you are finished. Then, under the Group Policies tab, click
Add to add a new SSL VPN group table. Next, type in the desired policy name, secondary
DNS, primary WINS, secondary WINS, and description. We'll leave IE Proxy settings disabled and
the Enable Split Tunneling box unchecked. Click Apply when finished. Now to connect, open up the AnyConnect Mobility
Client and enter an IP which is reachable from the WAN to the router, followed by the
default gateway port of 8443 set earlier. Click Connect. If you have user accounts set up you'll be
prompted to enter a username and password to connect. The login banner is then displayed which must
be accepted to continue. There should now be an SSL VPN connection
between your client device and the router. To quickly test this open up command prompt
and check the connection between your computer and the internal LAN IP of the router. Type the command "ping" followed by the address. By default, this will be 192.168.1.1. If you receive reply packets, this confirms
a connection was successful. At this point, you should have all the information
you need to use AnyConnect for basic SSL VPN connections for your RV340 and RV345 routers. I'm Keshav from Cisco, and thanks for watching.

title: Cisco Tech Talk: FindIT
description: Manage your entire network as a single system with Cisco’s new FindIT Network Management software. To learn more, visit the Cisco Small Business FindIT support page: http://cs.co/6007DEv1d.
transcript:
See this? It's a treadmill. As a network
administrator, you can probably relate because at the end of a full day of managing a bunch
of individual devices, you feel like you've been on a giant treadmill and not really going
anywhere. We'll talk about how to get more out of your day, next. You've been there,
right? Spending a ton of time managing individual devices and trying to keep track of hardware,
software, and licensing. Enter Cisco's FindIT Network Management. FindIT gives you a single
pane of glass solution where you can manage your entire network as a single system to
cut down on the time needed to maintain your network while increasing system uptime. FindIT
will automatically discover your network, and give you an affordable way to configure
all supported Cisco 100 through 500 series switches, routers, and wireless access points.
FindIT also sends you notifications about firmware updates and devices in your network
that are no longer under warranty or being supported. That way, you can be proactive,
not reactive. Let's break this down. FindIT has two applications: the probe and the
manager. The probe lives on the local network. And the manager can live anywhere as long
as probes communicate with it. In the past, FindIT was deployed strictly as a virtual
machine. Now, you can install it on your own hardware! FindIT also acts as a Cisco Plug
and Play server that lets you centrally manage firmware and configuration files for selected
devices. After the initial setup, configuration and firmware can be downloaded to a device
automatically. What about reporting? FindIT tracks 90 days worth of events. You'll get
a list of everything that happened in the network and you can filter the results to
whatever interests you. You can monitor network health and traffic, and even track any rogue
access points that might be slowing things down and posing a security risk. Upgrades
happen. You may be used to re-deploying a new virtual machine for every upgrade. With
FindIT, you'll get automatic upgrades to the probe and manager software without having
to re-deploy. Using Kaseya VSA? FindIT is so intuitive, it even has a plug-in to tie
its functionality right into Kaseya so you can see your devices for remote monitoring
and management. So think about it. No more treadmill. No more running in circles trying
to manage your network. With FindIT, you'll be a lean, mean IT machine. Thanks for watching
Tech Talks from Cisco. We'll see you next time.

title: Cisco Tech Talk: FindIT Backup and Restore
description: See how to backup and restore devices on Cisco’s FindIT Network Management. To learn more, visit the Cisco Small Business Support Community: http://cs.co/6004DEQhm.
transcript:
With Cisco's FindIT Network Management solution,
you can manage and monitor your entire network as a single system, which is a way better than
managing a bunch of individual devices. But you know what else FindIT does? It can also be used to back up and restore
your devices. We'll talk about it, next. Let's get right into it. Here's how to backup and restore devices
with FindIT Network Manager 1.1. First, you'll need to login to the FindIT
Network Manager using your credentials. Once you're in, the default view is this
map view. But let's go to the list view. Since the actual backup and restore processes
are actually handled on the probe, you have to cross-launch into your selected probe. Click on the site name and a pane will open
on the right hand side. You'll see a globe. Click the globe and it will cross launch you
into that probe. The first page that comes up is the Discover
Topology Map. In this example, you see a router, two access
points, and a switch. You also see three Voice Over IP phones. Normally, you'd have to log in to each device
directly to back up their configurations. With FindIT, you can do an all-in-one backup. Go to Actions, then Backup Configurations. I'll just put a note here: Network Backup
from FindIT 1.1, then click Save. Notice the little activity monitor up here
in the Task Center. Click on that and you can see the status of
what's happening. This shows the RV325 was a successful backup. The phones were not successful because they
don't have the ability to back up their configurations. And it looks like the other devices were successfully
backed up. You can now close that window. You can also just backup one device if you'd
like. Let's click on the switch. A side panel opens. Click on Actions, then Backup Configuration. Here you can actually do a backup of this
one device. We'll call this New Switch Backup. You'll see in the task window that it's
complete. You'll also see it there under the entire
network backup we did. Now let's say someone was managing this
device and made a mistake on the configuration and saved it. And let's say that misconfiguration was
causing issues. In that case, you can restore your device
to a previous configuration. Once you click on the device, go to Actions,
then Restore Configuration. Select the backup configuration you wish to
restore. Then click Confirm. The Task Center will show that it's actively
restoring. Click on that and get the pop out window again
so you can monitor the status of the job and see when it's restored. It's that easy. Backup and restore. Two more reasons FindIT Network Manager 1.1
is THE best way to keep your IT process humming along. Thanks for watching Tech Talks from Cisco. We'll see you next time.

title: Cisco Tech Talk: RV340 Series
description: See how the new series of Cisco RV340 routers can boost employee productivity and network performance for your small business. To learn more, visit the Cisco Small Business RV345 router support page: http://cs.co/6001DEvkc.
transcript:
Running a business without secure networking
is like driving a car without seatbelts. With constant exposure to internet threats,
businesses have to think about how to boost employee productivity and network performance
by limiting unwanted network traffic. We’ll talk about how, next. Small businesses are especially vulnerable
to security threats. In fact, the National Cyber Security Alliance
claims that each year 20% of small businesses experience a cyber attack. And a cyber attack might just be serious enough
to close a business down. With Cisco RV340-Series Security Routers,
businesses can protect their network from unwanted content and malicious websites without
compromising the online experience. This series has four routers to choose from
– the RV340, RV340W, RV345, and RV345P. Each model shares these important features:
Gigabit Ethernet ports, wired NAT performance, business grade firewalling, and secure internet
connectivity. Where they differ is in the number of LAN
ports.The RV340 has dual WAN ports for load balancing and failover. And four LAN ports for high performance connectivity. The RV340W has the same features, but with
wireless capabilities. The RV345 has dual WAN ports and an integrated
16 LAN port switch to allow for more space and more ports for all devices in the LAN. The RV345P takes it a step further by adding
Power Over Ethernet, or PoE, to help reduce the expense of installing electric power cabling. That allows for flexibility of delivering
power in places without outlets to devices like wireless access points or voice over
IP phones. No matter which router you choose, an easy
configuration setup wizard is there every step of the way. And Cisco AnyConnect Secure Mobile Client
Software is supported for iPhone, Android, Windows 10 or MacBook laptops. Block unwanted categories, dynamically blacklist
websites, and set individual policies for applications to keep the network safe. The RV340 Series from Cisco. Scalable. Secure. Affordable. It’s what small businesses need for the
ultimate in business efficiency. Thanks for watching Tech Talks from Cisco. We’ll see you next time.

title: Cisco Tech Talk: The WAP581
description: See an overview of the Cisco WAP581 Wireless-AC Dual Radio Wave 2 Access Point with 2.5GbE LAN. To learn more, visit the Cisco Small Business WAP581 support page: http://cs.co/6004DEvKQ.
transcript:
It’s no secret. Businesses these days are judged by their
Wi-Fi connection. That makes your job in IT pretty important
because you want the best experience possible for both staff and customers. We’ll take a closer look at the future of
high-speed wireless, next. So everyone’s mobile-happy these days, right? Connecting here, there, and everywhere – it’s
what we do. That’s where Cisco’s WAP581 Wireless Access
Point comes in. It’s the perfect solution for small businesses
looking for simple, easy-to-deploy Wi-Fi connectivity that’s secure and reliable. So what makes WAP581 tick? For starters, you get single point setup without
a controller for easy, cost-effective deployment of multiple access points. Another advantage of the WAP581 is a constant
signal stream to all devices with an even distribution of bandwidth without compromising
speed. In other words, you get 4x4 multiple-user, multiple-input,
multiple-output technology to help give people the connectivity and performance they’re
looking for. WAP581 also supports Dual Gigabit Ethernet
– 2.5 Gigabit and 1 Gigabit LAN with Energy Efficient Ethernet and Link Aggregation. Speaking of which, other great features of
the WAP581 include a guest access portal to allow internet access to guests without exposing
your internal network. The ability to create different bandwidth
rates for downloads and uploads. And the ability to customize data usage and
duration of use depending on the user. How do you know if everything is working the
way it should be? Simple, with easy-to-understand troubleshooting
tools like Wireless Spectrum Analysis to help you detect nearby sources of radio frequency
interference. Saving possibly one of the best things for
last. The WAP581 integrates seamlessly with the
Cisco FindIT Network Management Platform so you can manage and monitor your Cisco, 100,
300, and 500 Series Access Points. All from one single, intuitive dashboard. What could be better than that? Fast, reliable high-speed Wi-Fi. People don’t just want it. They expect it. And with the Cisco WAP581, you’re in a position
to deliver amazing connectivity at an even more amazing price. Thanks for watching Tech Talks from Cisco. We’ll see you next time.

Anytime a small business can operate like

title: Cisco Tech Talk: Configuring Router Access Lists
description: Introduction to Access Rules on Cisco Small Business Routers. To learn more, visit http://cs.co/6008DPtcp.
transcript: admit it there are times you'd like to control traffic flow and improve security on your network you can with access rules we'll talk about it next access rules also known as access control lists filter network traffic by controlling weather routed packets are forwarded or blocked at the routers interfaces here's how it works the router examines each packet to determine whether to forward or drop the packet based on services the network administrator specifies in the access rules in this example device a on the developmental engineering department network is blocked from services on the sales network while device B has full access access rules can be filtered by source and destination addresses that are either ipv4 or ipv6 you can also filter based on OSI layer 2 protocols access rules can be applied to specific or all interfaces depending on where you want to deny or permit filtered traffic select the source interface and or the destination interface or specify the addresses that will be impacted access rules are often used on edge routers which are often between your internal network and an external network such as the internet access rules can also be used to segment or restrict access departmentally like you saw in the example depending on your access rules criteria you may have multiple access lists defined before we go a little footnote access rules are not failsafe it's possible they can be hacked by sophisticated users because authentication is not required other security features on our v3 40 series products such as application control web filtering and content filtering can be used to further protect your network there you have it access rules will help you determine how and when certain traffic is allowed to pass through your network be sure to look for more videos on the topic of configuring and managing access rules thank you for watching Cisco tech talks we'll see you next time you [Music]

title: Cisco Tech Talk: Configuring a Virtual Access Point on WAP125
description: Learn how to configure a virtual access point on WAP125 routers. To learn more, visit http://cs.co/6001DP0Z1.
transcript: let's talk virtual access points also known as surface set identifier z' they're key to supporting multiple wireless users while optimizing your network infrastructure virtual access points segment the wireless local network into a max of for multiple broadcast domains configuring a virtual access point means that that access point would be able to support more wireless clients through different service set identifier x' or SSID s today we're going to walk through how to configure the virtual access point on a WAP 1:25 access point first log into the web-based utility of the WAP 125 and in the wireless section choose networks next choose the radio interface to configure your options our radio 1 on the 2.4 gigahertz band and radio 2 on the 5 gigahertz band in our example radio 1 is chosen click the plus button to add a virtual access point verify that the enabled checkbox is checked this is checked by default enter the VLAN ID that needs to be associated with the virtual access point here the virtual access point will be set up for VLAN 10 now it's time to enter the name of the wireless network this is also called the service set identifier or SSID it is a combination of letters and numbers up to 32 characters long in this example Cisco test is entered verify that the box for SSID broadcast is checked this will make the SSID visible when Wireless clients search for a wireless network the option is checked by default uncheck this option if you do not want the SSID visible in the list of networks when SSID broadcast is disabled connecting to the wireless network must be done manually you may also check the wireless multicast forwarding checkbox in the wmf column this will provide an efficient way to transfer multicast traffic on the wireless devices next it's time to choose one of three security types from the drop-down list select none to disable wireless security on the virtual access point this is not recommended as it would be prone to unauthorized access select WPA personal to implement Wi-Fi Protected access personal security on the virtual access point this is typically used in small office environments where a remote authentication dial and user service or radius server is not required select WPA enterprise to implement WPA security on the virtual access point this is typically used in larger office environments with a radius server in place next select one of three client filter modes from the drop down list selected disabled if the client filter feature is not in use select a local if the client filter list is stored locally in the access point select radius if the client filter list is stored in a radius server check the channel isolation checkbox to block communication between wireless clients on the same virtual access point the web device will still allow data traffic between wireless clients on the network across a wireless distribution system WDS link and with other Wireless clients associated with another virtual access point when channel isolation is disabled the web allows clients to communicate with one another normally in our example channel isolation is disabled check the band steer box to automatically reroute dual band supported clients from the 2.4 gigahertz band to the 5 gigahertz band in our example band steer is disabled if necessary you can also choose a scheduler profile from the drop-down list in this example no scheduler profile is configured on the web you can also associate a captive portal instance to a virtual access point the settings of the captive portal instance associated to the virtual access point will apply to clients who attempt to associate on the virtual access point in our example none is chosen finally click Save in the upper right hand corner and verify that the virtual access point is now configured by viewing the networks in the range of your wireless computer in our example a Mac computer is used it is connected wirelessly to the newly configured Cisco test virtual access point network congratulations you just configured a virtual access point on your web 125 access point thanks for watching Tech Talks from Cisco we'll see you next time [Music]

title: Cisco Tech Talk: Inter-VLAN Configuration on RV180 and RV180W

transcript: welcome to the inter VLAN configuration video I'm your host here to show you how to route traffic between separate VLAN hosts to reduce network broadcasts and increase security talk about
