transcript: in setting up a network having multiple paths between switches can be a good thing these redundant links serve as backup paths for traffic to ensure reliability however without proper management data packets might just keep bouncing between switches without ever reaching their destination this causes what's called a network loop which leads to congestion now throw in broadcast frames those are the messages sent to all devices within a certain area and you've got a recipe for trouble if caught in a loop these broadcasts can multiply clogging up the Network's bandwidth and potentially bringing it to a halt to tackle this you need the spanning tree protocol STP it's like a traffic director deciding which Pathways to close off so data flows smoothly without any Loops over time different flavors of STP have been developed each with enhancements to keep networks running more efficiently but there's no Universal best choice it depends on your Network's specific needs in this episode of Cisco tech talk I'll explain the distinct features and benefits of each STP variation [Music] next I'll start with the original STP it's defined by the I E 802.1d standard and is also known as common spanning tree CST STP was designed to support a single spanning tree instance for the entire Bridge Network this can cause slow convergence and less than optimal traffic flows if you have a small simple Network STP may be all you need pervan spanning tree plus is a Cisco enhanced version that creates a distinct 802.1d spanning tree for each VLAN within the network this means that each VLAN can have its own optimized path this is done to improve Network efficiency however if you have a lot of vlans you have to be careful these individual instances increase the CPU and memory usage if your network doesn't have the capacity for this it can cause problems on the network if you have a Cisco network with enough capacity and VLAN specific optimization is important to you this would be a good fit moving toward faster convergence times rapid spanning tree protocol rstp is defined by the i e 802.1w standard and also serves as an evolution of the original STP our STP significantly improves Network recovery times after topology changes if network uptime is your number one priority you may want want to select rstp rapid per VLAN spanning tree plus is Cisco's version of rstp it incorporates the benefits of pvst plus offering a separate instance of 802.1w for each VLAN the blend of Rapid convergence and per VLAN optimization makes it a good choice for Cisco Centric environments with multiple vlans that need quick recovery from failures the last option multiple spanning tree protocol mstp is defined by i e 802.1s it takes a different approach by mapping multiple vlans into a single spanning tree instance Cisco's implementation of this is known as multiple spanning tree MST this approach can reduce the resource load on network devices by decreasing the number of required instances while still providing faster convergence than the original STP mstp has VLAN mapping efficiency like no other if you have a large Network and are concerned about scalability this may be a good option for you on Cisco Catalyst 1200 and 1300 series switches you have some detailed selections you can make for STP in the web user interface menu under spanning tree click STP status and global settings here you can adjust the spanning tree State STP Loop loop backu stdp operation mode bpdu handling setting path cost default values and Bridge parameters one other option here is to switch the mode from basic to Advanced in the upper right hand corner of the screen on this Catalyst switch advanced mode gives you access to more configuration choices when setting up mstp and pbst the options for STP vary based on the model of the switch that's a wrap for this stdp beginners guide now you know the benefits and potential drawbacks of each and can decide which is the best fit for your network thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

transcript: call Mom calling Mom isn't technology amazing when I make a call I'm so glad I don't have to enter the phone number anytime I make a request it searches the contact list finds the corresponding number and enters it for me the domain name system DNS Works similarly for the internet in this episode of Cisco tech talk I'll explain how DNS works next [Music] to explain DNS I'll start with an example let's say you want to update the firmware on your Catalyst 1300 switch so you head over to your computer open a web browser and enter software. cisco.com the name is easy to remember but computers don't communicate with names they use IP addresses an IP address is a unique ique number that computers use to find each other and communicate online so to keep things simple for you you just type in the name from there the computer sends a request for the IP address it starts with a DNS server called a recursive resolver which your internet company typically provides you if it doesn't already know the IP address the resolver reaches out to another server if that Server doesn't know the IP address it puts in a request to a server that knows more IP addresses this process is repeated as needed until the IP address is retrieved and sent back to the resolver the resolver passes the IP address to the computer your computer uses this IP address to talk to the web server where the website is stored now you can communicate with the website in this example you would access and download the firmware you would need for your switch one more thing to note is that after a DNS query has been resolved the recursive resolver caches the results this temporarily saves the IP address so it can be retrieved from memory rather than going through the entire process again if you've noticed that sites you visit often get loaded quicker than others that may be why that's DNS in a nutshell can you believe that even with billions of public IP addresses out there this entire process usually happens in milliseconds that's impressive unless wait are DNS queries not resolved quickly for you if your web pages load slowly there are options you can switch to a public DNS server instead of the one from your internet service provider this may improve speed or reliability some may even provide additional features like parental controls or cyber security protections to see DNS in action I'll use a packet capture tool called Wireshark wire shark is a free software tool that captures packets of data sent and received over a network and lets you examine them in detail after starting wire shark I'll initiate a capture on the ethernet interface filter the traffic to show only DNS related data and visit a variety of popular websites you can see the DNS queries and responses in real time remember background applications on your computer may also generate DNS requests that you're not directly initiating for instance if you're curious about the IP address that corresponds to cisco.com filter the DNS traffic by the domain name and observe both ipv4 and IPv6 responses showing the specific IP addresses associated with that domain there you have it the basics of DNS and how it works to give you a good online experience thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

space next select the location and click next at this point you will be prompted to choose the type of Cisco MPP phone you are adding there are two options for adding the phone using the activation code or entering the phone's MAC address I will opt for the lad after clicking next add the phone's extension and click save it'll take a few minutes for the phone to appear online once the phone is added to the control Hub it should show as online and be registered under the new space you created you can verify this by clicking on the workspace where the phone should display as online Additionally you can see the phone under the devices section by clicking on the device you've created the phone should now have an IP address and show as online to enable the hot desking feature locate the worksspace scheduling option and enable hot desking by clicking save following this action the QR code will be prompted on the phone screen now that the workspace has been created with the shared device you can add the users navigate to management user and select the user you want to configure for hot desing remember that the customer must have a WebEx calling license to enable this navigate to edit license choose calling and enable WebEx calling save the configuration which will be similar to the process used when creating hot desking for this customer for example if you have location 123 you might assign the extension 103 save the configuration for users that already have WebEx calling enabled and require additional lines go to calling Under the user settings click on hot desking and configure the line add more Lines by clicking the plus sign after the devices and user settings are enabled in the WebEx control Hub hotking is ready for IP phones with the hot dusing feature enabled a QR code will be displayed on the screen a user initiat at sign in by scanning this code using the camera on their mobile phone if the WebEx app isn't already installed on that mobile device they will be directed to install it in the app they enter their organizational credentials select the desired booking time for their call and click book the phone may restart before the call is booked but then the customer's extension and phone number will be visible if the user ever needs to end their booking earlier than scheduled they can manually sign out via the phone by selecting settings hot desking and then sign out this can also be done through the WebEx app otherwise when the booked duration ends the user is automatically signed out there is one exception if there is an active call on the phone when the booked time expires the auto sign up will be delayed until the call ends therefore you should remember to end call calls before leaving the workspace you will not be able to sign out via the WebEx app if there is an active call on the phone after a manual or automatic sign out the phone will reboot to clear the session and all personal user information the QR code will once again show on the phone screen indicating it is ready for a new user there you have it hot desking giving you flexibility and efficiency within your office space no matter when or where employees work to get the job done thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

#Cisco #CBS350 #Catalyst1200 #Catalyst1300 #LEDlights #SwitchStatus #SwitchTroubleshooting #CiscoTechTalk #NetworkManagement #ITSupport #SmallBusinessNetworking
transcript: anytime a switch boots up and joins a network you can't help but notice the various LED lights across the front panel these lights aren't just for show they change color and blink to communicate everything from operational status to network performance with a glance you can get valuable information as long as you know the meaning behind the messages in this episode of Cisco tech talk I'll explain the LED lights on Cisco business 350 Catalyst 1200 and Catalyst 1300 switches [Music] next I'll start with the system LEDs this light is located on the front of the switch on the left side under the reset button when the switch is not receiving power the light is off once I power on the switch you can see a BL blinking green light this indicates that the switch is attempting to acquire an IP address from a DHCP server I'll connect a DHCP server to the switch once the light turns solid green it signifies that the switch is fully operational and has successfully obtained an IP address an additional color you may see is Amber a solid amber light indicates that the system has power but is not functioning correctly a blinking amber light suggests a potential Hardware or firmware issue next I'll move over to the port LEDs where each Port has its own set of indicators an unlit LED signifies that there is either no cable connected to the port or the port is inactive a blinking green light indicates data is being sent or received when the light is solid green there's a stable link presence with a connected device some switch models feature power over ethernet Poe functionality these ports are marked with a yellow line underneath them as shown here Poe ports send status messages as well a solid amber light indicates that Poe is being supplied to a connected device in this example an access point that requires Poe has been connected upon plugging it in the amber light illuminates indicating that Poe is being supplied when the light turns green it confirms that the link is active and functional the only other color you may see on a Poe Port is the color amber a blinking amber light means there is an issue it could be a warning identified by the software such as an STP blocking state or an error within the link suggesting that a configuration change may be needed one more helpful tip if you ever want to verify that Poe function is active on a port you can press and hold the reset button for 1 second after you release the button the LED should revert to Green that's all there is to it now you know how to gather information from the LED lights on your CBS 350 Catalyst 1200 or Catalyst 1300 switch thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

transcript: a boot loop occurs when a switch repeatedly restarts and never fully boots up getting stuck in a cycle of trying to start over and over again this can be frustrating so I'll get right to it in this episode of Cisco tech talk I'll show you how to troubleshoot a CBS Catalyst 1200 or Catalyst 1300 switch if it fails to boot properly next [Music] before I start I need to point out three models of switches that cannot follow these recovery steps if you have a CBS 28d a CBS 258 PPD or a catalyst 12008 TD switch you'll need to contact technical support these switches do not have a standard RJ45 console Port which is needed for troubleshooting see the link in the description for contact information for all other Swit switches you will need to connect your computer to the switch using a console cable console cables also known as rollover cables allow for serial communication between the switch and the computer a traditional console cable has an RJ45 connector on one end which plugs into the switch's console port and an RJ45 connector on the other end to connect to the computer's ethernet port since most modern computers do not have an RJ45 port port a USB to RJ45 console cable is often used this cable has a USB connector for the computer on one end and an RJ45 connector for the switch's console port on the other to communicate with the switch you will also need to download communication software on your computer I will use putty once your computer is connected to the switch via the console cable launch the putty application to configure putty you need to determine the appropriate serial line for your computer which can be found under the ports section and the device manager of your computer for instance on this laptop the USB serial Port is labeled as com 4 enter this information into the serial line field in your putty application next adjust the speed to 115200 and ensure that the connection type is set to Cal after completing these configurations click the open button in put to establish a connection to your Cisco Catalyst switch through the command line interface CLI once connected you'll be able to observe the reboot process of the switch watch for the message autoboot in 2 seconds press return or escape to abort and enter prom press the Escape key to initiate the recovery process after accessing the startup menu you'll be presented with several options to swap the active image image with the inactive one which will prevent you from losing your current configuration select option one image menu to proceed with option one select it and you will be given the choice to swap to inactive image or go back select option one confirm the swap by pressing the y key and the switch will reboot using the inactive firmware if the reboot worked that's great if not another option is to factory reset via the CLI this will erase all configurations to begin access the startup menu Once More by pressing the Escape key when you see the autoboot message in the startup menu choose option two erase configuration for the factory reset when prompted with are you sure press the y key followed by the enter key to confirm to finalize the recovery process and Trigger the factory reset select op option four exit startup menu which will reboot the switch and restore factory defaults there you have it two options to recover your switch if the factory reboot and reset methods don't work you can open a support case with your Cisco technical support team if you've never opened a case before or want some guidance see the link in the description for details thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

transcript: if you use the Cisco business dashboard CBD to monitor maintain and manage your network you can set it up to automate the process of installing or upgrading software images and installing configuration files on the devices that are deployed in a network for the first time this process is known as zero touch provisioning this helps manage the configuration and integration of the device it is done using the Cisco Network plug-in play P&P solution in this episode of Cisco tech talk I'll show you how to provision a Cisco business CBS Catalyst 1200 or catalus 1300 switch to automatically use the P&P connect redirection service using CBD as a PNP server next to begin visit the Cisco software website at software cisco.com navigate to the network plug-in Place section under smart licensing and select manage devices create the controller profile add a new profile by selecting PNP server as the controller type set a profile name and description select it as the default profile I'll leave the deployment type as customer hosted use the Cisco business dashboard as a P&P server and specify its IP address next you need to import The Cisco business dashboard P&P server certificate there are certain requirements to be aware of the P&P agent in this scenario the switch will validate the PNP server certificate Additionally the agent will check if the certificate's common name and subject alternative name match the host name or IP address of the P&P server if they do not match the certificate validation will be rejected in newer versions if a TLS certificate includes a subject alternative name field TLS clients should ignore the common name value instead look for a match in the subject alternative name list this means that if you visit the Cisco business dashboard and encounter the message server certificate does not contain your server address in the subject alternative name field you need to update the certificate to do this select update certificate and ensure the subject alternative name field reflects the actual IP address of the Cisco business dashboard click save and then okay a page refresh verifies that the certificate is now valid you can then click to download the certificate chain following this return to Cisco software Central input the IP address of the Cisco business dashboard and and upload the updated certificate browse for the certificate file and select it click next and then submit now that you have the controller profile configured you can add devices enter the device information manually click identify device and enter the details including the serial number base product ID etc for example this is a catalyst 24p 4G after selecting the newly created controller profile click save next and submit the status shows as pending redirection upon refreshing the switch interface expedite the process by navigating to the P&P session and selecting resume to send an immediate request without waiting for a timeout observe the status change to contacted this indicates that the switch has reached out to the P&P redirection server after further refreshes and some waiting time the status should update to redirect it and eventually to redirect is successful next go to the Cisco business dashboard access the provision section Network plug-in play and then enable devices here you should see the switch listed under the P&P enabled devices provision the switch by clicking on its host name select the appropriate device group usually the default one and then click next choose the latest image for the switch and the custom configuration that has been prepared during this process it's important to set up a username and a strong complex password additional settings such as enabling the CBD probe and selecting an access key can be configured at this point you also have the option to assign a static IP address to the switch when complete click next and then finish the status will change to pending after a few moments the status will change to provisioning you will see the switch provisioning the image and rebooting once the image has been provisioned the configuration process will begin upon completion you will see that the switch's status has been updated to provisioned logging into the switch should confirm that the change on the host name including the new IP address has been applied navigate to The Cisco business dashboard settings under the administration section to see that the switch is connected to Cisco business dashboard and probe operation is enabled and that's all there is to it you've set up zero touch provisioning using the P&P connect redirect services offered by Cisco thanks for watching I'll see you next time

of this video okay now in part one I went over options for setting up the platform to run CBD once that's ready you'll need to do the setup of the dashboard the system setup wizard will guide you through the basic system settings the settings must be consistent with your organization's infrastructure one of the options you can decide ahead of time is the type of certificate you want to use a certificate is necessary because when connecting to the dashboard each device checks to ensure the certificate presented by the Dashboard is valid and can be trusted at installation CBD generates a self-signed certificate to secure web and other Communications with the server across the internet you can keep this for a certificate if you go through the system setup wizard for the certificate option you can simply renew this self-signed certific certificate by clicking next which is the default when you log into the dashboard interface you may get a security warning but you can simply click to proceed other options including obtaining a let's encrypt certificate or purchasing a certificate from a thirdparty certificate Authority an important part of this setup is the Discovery and management of devices on each Network I'll start with your local network if you are using using a virtual machine or Linux to run the dashboard you can simply enable the local probe right in the dashboard system setup wizard it will perform network discovery and communicate directly with all the devices in your local network on behalf of the dashboard now if you have remote networks each one will need to be set up as either direct managed or probe managed a directly managed network is set up so that all devices that need management have a direct association with the dashboard this is recommended but not always an option because each device needs to have the ability to act as its own CBD agent the devices in the current Cisco business class portfolio have this ability when running the latest firmware but some older equipment may not to see if the devices in your network support direct management check the device support list if all your devices have direct management support you should set up a directly managed Network there is no limit to how many devices can be directly managed so it's a great option for larger remote networks for Guidance with setup follow the direct management section of the quick start guide and check out the Cisco tech talk CBD setup for direct manag devices if you have a remote Network that will be managed by CBD and the devices cannot be directly managed you will need to select probe managed and enable a probe instead there are a few options for a probe if you have a small number of devices to manage and your equipment is up toate you can enable an embedded Probe on a switch within the remote Network a firmware wizard will guide you through this process the embedded probe can manage up to 15 devices and 150 connected clients check that same device support list for a list of switches that have embedded probe support if you have more devices or users than an embedded probe can handle you can set up a software Probe on the remote network instead a software probe can run on a virtual machine Raspberry Pi or a Linux host it can typically manage up to 50 network devices keep in mind that only one probe should be enabled on a remote probe managed Network on a directly managed Network you do not enable a probe one last part of the setup I want to mention is entering the credentials for devices it starts the discovery process which takes some time you'll see the devices being discovered and added to the inventory summary as Discovery progresses the dashboard will provide an overview of the network infrastructure and notifications will alert you to the changes in status here's a quick overview of of all the resources we checked out today for reference there you have it there are plenty of customizations and other options with CBD but that's the basics to get it up and running now that you have seen an overview and some options for setup you can decide what will work best for you thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

transcript: in asymmetric routing data packets Take One path to reach their destination and a different path on their way back this may not sound like a big deal but it can lead to issues when stateful firewalls are part of the network path in this episode of Cisco tech talk I'll explain asymmetric routing some issues it can cause and how to reconfigure your network to prevent it next [Music] a firewall with stateful packet inspection looks closely at the first packet of data when it starts a new connection it remembers this information and keeps track of the conversation or flow if a packet comes in and it's part of the conversation the firewall remembers it lets it through conversely if the packet does not match or is not associated with an existing flow it is dropped protocols that maintain State information such as HTTP and TCP may be affected by asymmetric routing while stateless protocols such as icmp may not to illustrate the impact of asymmetric routing consider the following Network diagram in this network there is a layer 3 switch and a firewall with stateful packet inspection capabilities connected via a trunk link the switch has two connected devices a PC and a server each belonging to different vlans and subnets the firewall serves as the default gateway for the PC while the layer 3 switch is the default gateway for the server when the PC attempts to initiate a three-way TCP handshake with the server it sends a TCP sin packet to its default gateway the firewall the firewall then forwards the packet to the server in response the server sends a synac message which is directed to its default gateway the layer 3 switch the layer 3 switch consults its forwarding table and finds that the PC's VLAN is directly connected so it forwards the synak message directly to the PC the PC then attempts to complete the hand Shake by sending a TCP act message back to the server through the firewall its default gateway however the firewall performing stateful packet inspection drops this act packet because it did not see the syac coming from the server and therefore has no established Flow State for this connection in practice to demonstrate this Behavior a layer 3 switch could be connected to an RV 34 45 router with firewall capabilities that include stateful inspection for example two ipv4 interfaces on the switch could be set up for VLAN 1 and VLAN 2 with corresponding interfaces configured on the router the router and switch would be connected via a trunk link a PC might be connected to an access port on the switch that is a member of VLAN 2 with a static IP address configured and the fire firewalls IP address in VLAN 2 set as its default gateway a server with an IP address in VLAN 1 might also be connected in this setup while the server responds to Ping requests attempts to access it through other protocols May Fail checking the firewall logs would reveal that the firewall is dropping the TCP act messages from the PC to resolve this a few reconfigurations are needed on the network work set up the firewall or the switch as the default gateway for both the server and the PC in this example by changing the default gateway on the PC to the IP address of the layer 3 switch within VLAN 2 the asymmetric routing issue will be resolved there you have it the basics of asymmetric routing and how to prevent it in your network thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

operations logging events and coordinating tasks across a network by using sntp servers network devices can adjust to the correct time from a designated time Source thus ensuring consistency across the system this is particularly important for security data integrity and troubleshooting in this episode of Cisco tech talk I'll show you how to configure the correct time settings on Cisco business CBS Catalyst 1200 and Catalyst 1300 series switches [Music] next I'll start with a switch that has been factory reset integrated into the network and has already obtained a DHCP IP address the display the time on your CBS or Catalyst switch using sntp servers thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

transcript: have you been dealing with slow Wi-Fi if you're in a densely populated area other wireless networks may be interfering with yours causing the Slowdown there's a simple solution you can try in this episode of Cisco tech talk I'll show you how to adjust the channel settings on your Cisco business wireless cbw access point to speed up your Wi-Fi network next [Music] one thing everyone appreciates is a fast Wi-Fi connection it's as great as the feeling of driving down an open road with nothing in your way one of the ways to shoot for faster speeds on a wireless network is to set a wider Channel width it allows more data to flow just like a highway with many lanes for example on the 5 GHz frequency an 80 MHz Channel width combines 4 20 MHz channels this results in a broader channel that allows greater speed and faster data transfer rates seems like a simple selection if you can expand your channel withd without causing conflicts that's what's recommended however channels just like highways are shared more traffic leads to congestion and interference it may not be the the best option in every situation determining the Channel width you should configure depends on the other networks around you for example if you were to set up a network within 80 MHz width spanning channels 36 to 48 and your neighbor used channels 44 to 48 there would be overlap in this case instead of a broader Channel you would be better off selecting a 20 or a 40 mehz width to avoid interference I'll demonstrate how you can try adjusting and checking the results on your network start with a quick speed test in this example my download and upload speeds are somewhat slow with the current settings navigate to the cbw web user interface under the monitoring section select clients and then Network summary here you can view the network topology of the device and assess the connection score the overall score is low and the actual rate for the client is slow although the access point and the client both support two spatial streams the problem appears to be with the Channel width settings the AP is configured for a 20 MHz Channel width while the client can handle up to 160 MHz to address this I'll proceed to wireless settings select access points and then adjust the Channel width under Radio 2 for the 5 GHz band change the setting to an 80 MHz Channel width and also opt for the automatic selection this automatic setting means that the channel will automatically be selected based on its availability this is helpful to avoid interference it's important to note that this option is not available on mesh extenders after confirming the changes you can see the connection score has improved to 100% And the client's actual rate is significantly higher returning to the speed amount of interference be sure to save the changes on your cbw web user interface that's all there is to it now you know how to adjust the channel settings on your cbw access point to avoid Wireless interference thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

transcript: in today's digital age understanding the flow of data within a network is crucial for maintaining its health and efficiency the onboard packet capture OPC tool lets you capture and analyze data packets that are transmitted across a network it's particularly useful for troubleshooting issues or monitoring Network performance in this episode of Cisco tech talk I'll explain onboard packet capture OPC via CLI on Catalyst 1200 and 1300 switches starting with version 4.1.3 next I'll start by explaining some parameters starting with capture points when you set up a capture point you are essentially defining a policy or a set of criteria that determines which packets will be captured this can include the direction of traffic incoming outgoing or both or specific types of packets they are essentially designated spots within the network where data packets can be collected for analysis you can only have one capture Point active at any given time a maximum of four capture points can be configured on a switch the capture points are configured in privileged exec mode on the switch they are not saved to the switch's configuration files and do not persist after a reboot a capture is allocated to a maximum of 20 MBT of memory it can be stored in memory and then saved to the onboard flash memory of the switch provided there is enough free space or to an external attached USB flash drive it's important to note that it may use a considerable amount of CPU resources so it's recommended this feature is used only when necessary now I'll go over the commands you will use for OPC on a Cisco Catalyst 1200 or 1300 switch to start it is recommended that before starting a packet capture you check CPU utilization with the command show CPU utilization you can verify the firmware version by typing the command show version in privileged exec mode to create a capture enter the command monitor capture followed by the name of the capture such as cap one which I will reference as its name moving forward when a capture point is created you can view its details with the command show monitor capture to remove a capture Point use the command no monitor capture followed by its name it will delete that specific capture point to verify it is gone enter a show monitor capture command the reply of no capture exist confirms it for buffer related settings the command is Monitor capture cap 1 buffer then specify the size and buffer mode which can be either linear the default or circular the default buffer size is 5 mbes the minimum buffer size is 1 and the maximum is 20 in this example the buffer size is 4 mbes to view buffer details use the command show monitor capture cap 1 buffer the details will be listed to clear the buffer enter monitor capture cap 1 clear which will prompt you for confirmation enter y to specify the source interface for the capture enter monitor capture cap 1 followed by The Source type which is currently only supported for the control plane you also need to specify the direction of the packets to capture which can be inbound outbound or both the capture filter settings are mandatory although with this first release filter operations are not yet supported so for now set parameters using the any option this full command is Monitor Capture One cap 1 match any when ready start the packet capture with monitor capture cap 1 start to stop the capture enter monit monitor capture cap 1 Stop once the capture is done you can save the data from the buffer which is Ram to either the switches onboard flash or a USB storage device this is done using the monitor capture cap 1 export command followed by the destination path I'll save it to flash a success notification verifies that it has been saved I'll save it to USB as well to see the location of these files navigate to the web user interface of your Catalyst switch select administration file management and then file directory you can see that the packet capture file has been saved to both The Flash and USB drives as of version 4.1.3 you cannot open and view this file on the switch itself but you can transfer it to a laptop or PC for further analysis that's all there is to it nice you have a convenient way to collect and store packet data for monitoring and troubleshooting on your Catalyst switch thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

transcript: Port security is a safeguard in computer networks that allows only approved devices to connect to a network switch by checking their unique Mac address it's a basic Network defense at layer 2 preventing unauthorized access and attacks like mac flooding in such attacks hackers overload the switch with fake Mac addresses causing confusion and misdirected Network traffic Port security keeps the network secure by ensuring only recognized devices can connect in this first of a two-part episode of Cisco tech talk I'll explain the port security modes on Cisco Catalyst 1200 and 1300 series switches [Music] next there are four modes of Port Security on these switches classical lock limited Dynamic lock secure permanent and secure delete on reset I'll go through each of them so you can see the behavior with each Port mode setting and explain why you might choose that specific mode in classical lock mode all learned Mac addresses on a port are locked meaning the port will not learn any new Mac addresses any addresses that had been learned already are not subject to aging or relearning classical lock is ideal for situations where a switch Port is dedicated to a single device or a set number of devices this might be a server or a workstation that does not change frequently it ensures that no unauthorized devices can connect to the port as the Mac addresses are locked down this is designed to provide a high level of security to demonstrate how this works I'll access the web UI of a catalyst 1300 switch that is running on my network and go into advanced mode looking at the dynamic address table for Port three there were three Mac addresses already learned I'll head to Port security settings select Port G3 and enable classical lock I'll leave the action on violation set to discard which is the default and enable trap for CIS log messages after applying these settings a CIS log notification lets me know that the port has been locked now when I re visit the MAC address table you can see that the static addresses are populated with the Mac addresses from Port 3 adding a new Mac address to this port will result in a violation message as the new address will be discarded due to the violation of classical lock it's important to note that if no Mac addresses have been learned on a port by the time classical lock is enabled the port will not learn any new addresses to illustrate rate this I'll lock Port 5 with classical lock after applying the new settings the MAC address table shows no learned addresses on Port 5 any attempt to add a new Mac address will fail it will be discarded and the corresponding message will show another key point is that when a secure Mac address is seen on a different port the frame is forwarded but the MAC address is not learned on that new port for instance if I disconnect a client from Port 3 and connect it to another Port the port becomes active but no Mac address is learned on the New Port Mac address will only be expected on Port ge3 no entry will appear in the dynamic address table for Port ge1 furthermore static address entries will remain in the table even after a reboot of the switch provided you save the running configuration I'll demonstrate this by saving this configuration and disconnecting everything from Port 3 after rebooting the switch you can see the entries are still there the second Port security mode is limited Dynamic lock in this mode the device learns Mac addresses up to a configured limit of allowed addresses once the limit is reached no additional addresses are learned and the addresses are subject to aging and relearning this may be a a good option in environments where there is a need to limit the number of devices that can connect to a port but you need some flexibility for device changes this mode might work best in a conference room or a classroom where different users May connect their devices at different times but the total number of simultaneous connections should be controlled to demonstrate limited Dynamic lock I'll go to the port security settings for Port 7 select limited dynamic lock set the maximum number of allowed addresses to three and apply the settings then I'll lock the port select discard on violation enable trap for messages and click apply by navigating to the dynamic addresses option under the MAC address tables menu you can then observe that after adding three Mac addresses the limit is reached and any additional addresses are discarded these are dynamic entries on Port 7 so upon removing the connected device on Port 7 these three entries will get deleted that's a wrap on part one click the link in the description for part two where I'll explain and demonstrate the last two Port security mode options thanks for watching I'll see you soon [Music]

transcript: change of authorization COA is a way for Network administrators to change the properties of an authentication authorization and accounting AAA session after it has been authenticated starting with version 4.1.3 this feature is available on Catalyst 1300 switches Cisco identity Services Engine Ice can be used as a dynamic authorization client to test this functionality in this first of a three-part episode of Cisco tech talk I'll explain COA on Cisco Catalyst 1300 series switches next I'll start with some important details of COA and how it works with the Catalyst 1300 switches COA follows a set of RFC based extensions specifically RFC 35 75 and 5176 to the radius protocol when a policy for a user or group within triaa changes an administrator can send radius COA packets from the AAA server ice to reinitialize authentication and apply the new policy a dynamic authorization client the radius server sends a disconnect or COA message to the dynamic authorization server the switch this is the reverse of the typical radius terminology where the switch is considered the radius client and the ice is the radius server effective communication between the dynamic authorization client and server is essential meaning the switch and the ice must have direct connectivity however they do not need to be on the same subnet this network diagram provides further details about the operation and the direction of requests COA requests as outlined in RFC 5176 are utilized for session identification host reauthentication and session termination the model includes a single COA request and two possible response codes COA acknowledgement COA act and COA non acknowledgement COA Knack a COA client typically a radius or policy server initiates the request which is then received by The Listener device if an authorization status is successfully modified a COA Act is returned with the attributes varying based on the COA request conversely a COA Knack indicates a failure to change the authorization State and may include attributes that specify the reason for the failure COA is an extension to the radius protocol call with the ice sending packets to UDP Port 1700 by default on the switch supported commands and responses include 40 this is a disconnect request which is processed by the switch the switch replies with either a 41 disconnect act or a 42 disconnect Knack 43 is COA request processed by the switch the switch repli with either 44 COA AC or 45 COA Knack once COA is configured on the switch you can utilize its features from within ice that brings me to the end of part one click the link in the description to be brought to part two where I'll show how to utilize its features from within ice thanks for watching I'll see you soon [Music]

transcript: switches make sure traffic is managed and directed efficiently in a local network they support high bandwidth and low latency making them ideal for environments that require fast and reliable data communication When selecting a switch there are many key factors to consider the number of ports the speed of the ports power over ethernet capabilities and so much more a good place to start is to decide if you want a layer two switch for simple network connectivity or a layer 3 switch with Advanced routing capabilities in this episode of Cisco tech talk I'll explain the differences between layer 2 and layer three switches next both layer 2 and layer three switches manage the flow and prevent collisions efficiently handle ing traffic within the local network the fundamental difference is how they forward frames layer 2 switches use Mac addresses to forward frames within the same network they help handle data efficiently reduce Network congestion are coste effective and can be simple to deploy layer three switches have the capabilities of both a layer to switch and a router but instead of Mac addresses they use IP addresses to to forward frames this lets them route packets within the same network in between different networks in addition many layer 3 switches offer Advanced features that aren't available on a layer 2 switch many come with Advanced security features such as Access Control lists to control and filter traffic based on IP addresses protocols and ports these enhance network security by providing more granular control over data flow they can often make routing decisions faster than traditional routers because they're optimized for high-speed data processing most offer quality of service features for the prioritization of critical Network traffic this is important if your company uses applications that require high bandwidth and low latency like Voiceover IP or video conferencing some even support Advanced routing protocols providing failover capabilities in case of device or link failures so in a nutshell a layer 3 switch is more powerful and offers more features than a layer 2 switch When comparing switches typically a switch with a higher model number will have more features and advanced options but will cost more and may be more complex to set up it's a good idea to check each model to see which one fits your needs and budget best if you have a small Network you might want a sis business 110 unmanaged switch these layer 2 switches are not configured and are essentially plug-and playay some models in this series have power over ethernet ports so you can easily add and power devices to your network like IP cameras phones and wireless access points the CBS 220 smart switches are also layer 2 A step above the 110 they have some configuration options including some support for vlans Cisco business 250 smart switches are layer three switches that provide static routing they are designed to be cost effective while still offering essential features like VLAN segmentation and intervlan communication a step up from there is the CBS 350 managed switches these offer a higher level of control than the 250 with custom configurations Remote Management and advanced features like vlans Port security authentication and traffic prioritization there are also some stacking options within this series Cisco Catalyst 1200 switches provide layer three static routing capabilities they can manage internal routing within a network by directing traffic between different VLS using statically configured routes without the need for a dedicated router for basic Network segmentation Catalyst 1300 series switches provide Dynamic layer 3 routing allowing for efficient intervalent communication without degrading application performance they're designed to handle high bandwidth applications and Technologies wow there are so many options for managing data traffic which features are essential for your business now and in the future well luckily that's up to you thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

transcript: plug-in play PNP it's a feature that simplifies the setup of network devices for some Electronics like a keyboard mouse USB flash drive or computer monitor it's almost as simple as the name you simply connect it from there it recognizes what is needed figures out the right settings and applies them automatically plug-in play saves time with installation increases productivity and reduces the chance of human error Cisco network plug-and-play is a service that works with network PNP enabled devices including Cisco business CBS Catalyst 1200 and Catalyst 1300 switches it centrally manages firmware and configurations it also provides zero Touch provisioning of new devices in this episode of Cisco tech talk I'll explain Network plug- andplay P&P for beginners next [Music] for Network PNP to work PNP enabled devices must locate the P&P server the devices can find this server in several ways the first is by manual configuration entering the details about the server directly into the device beyond that the server can be found through DHCP Discovery DNS discover recovery or PNP connect redirection Services these methods are prioritized starting with manual configuration the PNP server is integrated with the Cisco business dashboard if manually configured the PNP client will attempt to connect directly to the P&P server if manual configuration is not used the P&P client will first try to locate the P&P server using the DHCP Discovery method to discover the server address using DHCP the device will send a DHCP discover message with option 60 that contains the string Cisco PNP the DHCP server must send a response containing the vendor specific information option option 43 the device extracts the PMP server address from this option and uses this address to contact the server if this fails the DNS Discovery method is used based on the network domain name returned by the DHCP server the device constructs a fully qualified domain name for the server using the preset host name PNP server if the DNS Discovery is also unsuccessful the P&P client will reach out to the P&P connect redirection services this is when the device goes online to find directions to the server therefore the P&P client must have have internet access you need to create a controller profile for the P&P server on software. cisco.com then each device must be registered the P&P client will then attempt to connect to device helper. cisco.com there are certain considerations to keep in mind if using the https transport protocol the PNP client will verify that the certificate presented by the P&P server is valid and trustworthy the certificate must either be signed by a trusted certificate Authority CA or it must be independently trusted by the client Additionally the P&P agent ensures that the certificate's subject alternative name aligns with the host name or IP address of the P&P server ensure the value matches if there is a mismatch the certificates validation will be rejected there you have it now you know how Network P&P can work for you thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

transcript: imagine you're planning a road trip you have a map and you know your destination but there are multiple routes you could take some routes are faster some are Scenic and some might be closed due to construction to make your journey smooth you plan the route ahead of time marking the best roads to take this way you avoid getting lost and ensure you reach your destination efficiently in the world of networking static IP routes work similarly they help data packets find their way through a network ensuring they reach the correct destination without unnecessary detours in this first of a two-part episode of Cisco tech talk I'll explain the basics of static routes next routers are great multitaskers they can receive routing information from various sources simultaneously including connected interfaces static routes or dynamic routing protocols static routes are manually configured with a predefined path to direct data traffic from one network to another to do this you specify the IP address of the destination Network and the next hop the destination IP address tells the router where the data is ultimately headed while the next hop IP address indicates the next device in the path that will forward the packet closer to its final destination this is unlike Dynamic routing where routes are automatically adjusted based on network conditions one of the main advantages of static routes is their Simplicity in smaller networks where the number of routes is limited they can efficiently manage traffic without the complexity of dynamic routing protocols for stable networks where the topology doesn't change frequently static routes provide a reliable way to ensure data reaches its destination limiting the routes data can take lowers the risk of unauthorized access or data breaches it provides predictability which is important for applications that demand consistent performance they can also serve as backup routes if primary Dynamic routes fail ensuring Network redundancy and reliability static routes give complete control over the routing paths enabling fine-tuned optimization of network traffic moreover they reduce overhead because they do not require the constant communication and computation that Dynamic routing protocols do while static IP routes offer many benefits they also come with limitations scalability can be an issue in large dynamic networks managing static routes can become convers some and lead to errors they can be timec consuming to maintain since they don't adapt when there is a change in the network topology or if there's a failure manual updates need to be done if they aren't done quickly or properly there will be problems in the network by understanding when and how to use static routes you can ensure efficient and reliable Network performance one static route that almost every network administrator sets up is a default route a default route directs all traffic that doesn't match any other specific routes in the routing table to a designated next hop typically a router that connects to the internet or another large Network this ensures that any data packets with unknown destinations can still be forwarded appropriately providing a catch-all path for outbound traffic and ensuring basic network connectivity to match any destination Network address and subnet map 0.0.0.0 is used for both there you have it the basics of static routes click the link in the description for part two where I'll show you how to configure them thanks for watching I'll see you soon [Music]

transcript: welcome back in this second of a two-part episode of Cisco tech talk I'll show you how to configure static routes on a router and a layer 3 switch next for this demonstration I've set up a specific Network topology it includes layer 3 switches which means they are routing capable the switches are connected over VLAN 100 using access ports this configuration allows vlans with identical names to exist on both switches without causing any conflicts for instance both switches can have a VLAN one assigned to different subnets and since there is no trunk link between the switches there's no conflict to demonstrate static routing I have connected my PC labeled PC3 to an access port that is a member of VLAN 15 on layer 3 switch I've assigned a static IP address to my PC which resides within the subnet of VLAN 15 from PC3 I can easily access PC2 which is in VLAN 25 I can verify connectivity by sending icmp requests to a device in vlan25 and receiving responses however pinging pc1 in VLAN 20 presents a different situation PC 1 is connected to switch a and there is no direct layer 2 or layer 3 communication path to it attempting to Ping pc1 will show no connectivity to establish this connectivity we need to create static routes first I'll connect to switch B to create a static route I will show that both switches are interconnected through VLAN 100 over access ports which are Port one on each switch in the ipv4 configuration I will set a static route indicating that to access network 10.20 20.0 sl24 packets must be directed to the next hop which is the IP address of layer 3 switch a after applying the static route it's crucial to note that although switch B can now direct packets correctly switch a still won't be able to Route the return icmp replies because it has no route to the network of PC3 to address this I'll connect to switch a via a console cable and create the necessary static route using the command line interface CLI after entering the global configuration mode on switch a I'll use the command IP route to create a static route if I want to reach Network 10.15.1 15.24 I must direct the packets to switch B which has the IP address 10.1 100.1 100.2 to confirm that the static route has been added I'll type show IP route and observe that the static route is present in the routing table now consider accessing the internet here the default route becomes critical as it usually provides access to the public network or the internet to illustrate this I'll change the configuration slightly by adding a connection through VLAN 1 to a router which will provide internet access and the default route the default route is usually indicated by 0.0.0.0 sl0 in the routing table this route can be obtained either statically through manual configuration or dynamically from a DHCP server connecting the switch to the router will result in the switch receiving an IP address for VLAN 1 from the DHCP server refreshing the static routes will display the default route provided by the DHCP server it's important to note that by default the router will only provide internet access to clients in VLAN 1 to extend internet access to other networks such as VLAN 15 an additional static route must be added to the router to ensure return internet packets can find their way back to the correct network if you log into the router and navigate to the static routing section you can see the static route that has been been created for Network VLAN 15 without this static route the router would not know how to route return packets from the internet to manually create a default route on switch a the following configuration command would be used IP route 0.0.0.0 to match any destination Network address then 0.0.0.0 to match any subnet mask the last IP address is the the next hop address that the packet should be sent to on its way to the Final Destination usually a router that's all there is to it now you can configure static routes using the web user interface or via CLI thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

the switch enable the advanced view in the upper right corner to view the vlans on the switch navigate to VLAN management and then VLAN settings on this network the switch has already been configured as a layer 2 switch with router on a stick configurations and three vlans each of these vlans needs to be configured with a switch virtual interface SBI to enable l ler 3 switching to do this go to repeat repeat the same process for any other vlans in my case that's VLAN 3 create a layer 2 interface with an IP address to Route traffic Upstream once layer 3 functionality is enabled on this port choose the interface connected to your router or firewall device this example interface 35 is connected to my router I will assign it to the IP address of 192168491 of 255.255.255.0 and click apply next to ensure all vlans can communicate with each other using the switch as the Gateway enable ipv4 routing and apply this will also allow routing among all layer 3 interfaces to create a Gateway for layer 3 traffic go to ipv4 static routes and add a default gateway I'll enter 0.0 0.0 for the IP address and the subnet mask with the next hop of [Music] 192168491 process ensure that in your DHCP server pool the default router is the switch and the domain name server is either Google or your isp's DNS server then head over to the switch UI and change the interface connecting with the router to layer three select VLAN management and then interface settings scroll down to the switch interface that will be the Uplink in my case that's interface 35 select it and click the edit icon change the switch Port mode from Layer Two to layer three click apply this will disable connectivity with the switch since layer 2 traffic was disabled for this specific port to establish connectivity using layer three you must set up layer three return static routes on your connecting router or firewall I'll use an rv260w router to configure the routes back to the switch if you are not using an RV series router follow the instructions for layer three routing that are specific to that device instead log into the web UI of the router before the routes are entered some changes need to be made go to Lan and ban settings since the 192168101 network is no longer directly connected to the router I'll change VLAN 1 to 192.168 5.1 and click apply log in with the new IP address to get back into the web UI of the router I'll delete vlans 2 and 3 and create VLAN 4 with an IP address of 192168491 and click apply one once everything is prepared you can put in the return routes navigate to routing and then static routing click the add button enter the IP address of the network subnet mask and next hop repeat this process for the rest of the networks on the switch press apply it should be set yes my computer has picked up an IP address from the Catalyst switch on VLAN 1 and is using the switch as the default gate way with the IP address of 192.168.10.0 great I can successfully communicate with the devices on the switch be sure to save all these new configurations your Catalyst 1300 switch is set to use layer 3 routing providing the flexibility performance and security you need to support your growing business thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

transcript: welcome back now that you understand why quality of service qos is important I'll detail some key components that make it work in this second of a two-part episode of Cisco tech talk I'll finish explaining qos and demonstrate how to set it up on a catalyst 1300 switch [Music] next to achieve quality of service qos networks use several mechanisms to manage and prioritize traffic the process begins with classification where packets are identified and labeled using tools like Access Control lists ACLS differentiated Services code point dscp and class of service cosos an ACL is an ordered set of rules that helps filter data controlling what data comes in or goes out of a network interface cosos is a value in the VLAN tag at layer 2 that helps prioritize data frames frames from specific vlans are prioritized using the 802.1 Q tag a cosos value stays with the frame as long as the VLAN tag is there once the tag is removed the cosos value is gone dscp works at layer three and is included in the IP header it stays with the packet from start to finish helping prioritize it throughout its Journey unfortunately dscp values can be changed by network devices along the way so even if you set them they might be altered by devices you don't control qos marking helps prioritize important data to ensure it gets through quickly and reliably this marking creates different classifications of service for different types of data marking can be done at layer two layer three or both at Layer Two you mark the cosos value at layer three you set the type of service field in the IP packet header shaping controls the maximum rate of data to prevent congestion it limits the data sent from an interface policing sets an upper limit for data it helps manage Network traffic based on predefined rules if there's too much data it can be remarked or dropped queuing helps prevent congestion by sending data to specific cues for processing data is then sent out based on bandwidth allocation bandwidth allocation determines how much capacity is available for data subject to qos rules trust mechanisms in network devices help keep data quality consistent when a device trusts incoming data it passes through with its priority settings intact in the absence of any explicit policy configuration Upstream references data coming into the device Ingress Downstream references data leaving the device egress this ensures that important data gets treated the same way across the network on Cisco 1200 or 1300 series switches qos can be set up in basic or advanced mode on the qos properties page you can configure qos in basic mode there's an option to Define a trusted domain where packets are marked with 802.1p priority and or dscp to Signal their service type nodes in the domain use these fields to assign packets to specific output cues initial packet classification and marking are done at the Ingress of The Trusted domain to set the trust mode for basic qos settings go to the global settings page Define trust mode as either cosos DSC P or both once selected traffic will be mapped accordingly if you choose both either cosos or dscp will be used you may enable override Ingress dscp to change the original dscp values in incoming packets with new ones when enabled the device uses the new dscp settings for outgoing data and replaces the original ones in the packets to modify the dscp output click apply to save the changes on the interface settings page there's an option to enable or disable qos on each port to do this select a port click edit and make your selection if disabled all incoming data on the port goes to the best effort queue with no classification or prioritization if enabled the port prioritizes data based on the systemwide trusted mode either cosos or dscp click the save icon to apply the settings there you have it setting up a network for your small business doesn't have to be daunting qos helps your network run efficiently providing a better experience for both your customers and your staff thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

transcript: Cisco business Dashboard Light is a simplified version of The Cisco business dashboard CBD it retains essential features while reducing complexity and resource usage this option is ideal for users who need basic functionality without the full Suite of hardware and software in this episode of Cisco tech talk I'll explain the basic features and functionalities of Cisco business dashboard CBD light [Music] next CBD light automatically discovers your network and lets you configure and monitor supported devices on your network it also notifies you about firmware updates and devices that are no longer under warranty or covered by a support contract at release version 2.8.0 it supports only English however future releases are planned to include translations into other languages such as Chinese French German Japanese Portuguese and Spanish the tool uses several protocols to manage devices including multicast DNS mdns DNS service Discovery also known as bonjour Cisco Discovery protocol CDP link layer Discovery protocol llddp rest and proprietary web service apis to discover the network it initially builds a list of devices by listing to mdns advertisements then it connects to each device using supported protocols to gather additional information such as CDP and lldp adjacency tables this information helps identify other devices in the network repeating the process until all devices are discovered see BD light doesn't actively scan the broader network but you can manually search an IP address range for manageable devices when this is done the dashboard will attempt to connect to web servers https ports on each IP address in the specified range to determine if a device is manageable now you may be wondering if the configuration of a new device will change once it's discovered well that depends if network configuration profiles have been enabled the configuration will be applied to newly discovered devices if the network configuration profile is disabled the devices configuration will not change for CBD light to work correctly it needs to use certain ports and protocols TCP Port 4443 is used for inbound https secure web access to the dashboard TCP Port 443 is used for for outbound https device management Port UDP 5353 is used for mdns protocol for device discovery on the local network the app communicates with several Cisco servers for various purposes for instance apex.com is used to retrieve software update information and product life cycle details dl. cisco.com and download sscc.edu used for downloading software updates Cloud ss1 cisco.com is used to authenticate CBD light before it communicates with apex.com here are some of the major differences between full CBD and the light version at release CBD light operates on Microsoft Windows only while CBD supports various virtualized environments including VMware virtual box and hyperv it can also be installed directly on Linux the light version must be on the same network as the managed devices full CBD can be used from any convenient location even if it's hosted in the cloud and managed devices are behind Network address translation no configuration changes are necessary for CBD light however the full version requires device configuration changes enabling the CBD agent and establishing an active connection you can find more detailed comparisons online including a list of devices supported by CBD light and their minimum firmware versions there you have it it's a simple as that if you would like to install CBD light on your Windows system click the link in the description thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

transcript: to get the latest features security patches and performance improvements available for your switch you should always update to the latest firmware version available it sets up your business for Less downtime improved productivity and a more secure environment if you're a fan of using the web user interface for these updates click the link in the description in this episode of Cisco tech talk I'll show you how to upgrade a catalyst 1200 or 1300 series switch using the command line interface CLI [Music] next start by connecting a console cable to establish a connection between the switch and your computer to test the connectivity open a command prompt and ping the IP address of the switch if you receive replies it means the connection is established next open a session to find the correct com Port go to the device manager and check under ports for example if it shows Comm 6 configure putty to use Comm 6 set the speed to 115200 and click open press enter to access the switch the next step is to download the most recent software version for your switch model this is available at software. cisco.com in this example I'm using a catalyst 1300 with 48 ports download the appropriate file and remember the directory where you saved it you will also need a tftp server open it and set the current directory to the path where you Sav the downloaded file ensure the server interface uses the IP address of your computer which acts as the server to find your computer's IP address open the command prompt and type ip config note the IP address of the ethernet port connected to the switch in this example it is 192.168.1 55 return to the switch and type the show version command to see the current software version for example if it shows version 4.0.0 91 and you want to upgrade to version 41336 proceed with the following steps first on the switch type boot system tftp followed by the IP address of your computer I'll enter mine 192.168.1.5 copy the full name of the downloaded image file including the file extension paste the file name after the IP address in the command and press enter the switch will start the upgrade process which may take several minutes you can monitor the activity on the tftp server and see the transfer occurring if you encounter any reachability issues check your firewall and proxy settings to make sure they aren't blocking the communication once the transfer is complete the switch will boot up enter the command show version If the previous version is still listed you will need to do another reboot of the switch this should load the new image after this reboot type the command show version one more time you should now see the new version in this case 41336 the upgrade was a success that's all there is to it your Catalyst switch is up to date thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

transcript: a switch connects devices within a local area network so they can communicate and share resources efficiently switches with power over ethernet Poe ports provide both connectivity and power to devices like IP phones security cameras and wireless access points this simplifies installation offers centralized control and enhances safety all great benefits the downside anytime the switch loses power Poe devices also lose power and connectivity this disrupts Poe operation until the device is fully restarted if your business relies on an uninterrupted power supply to critical network devices this downtime could cause huge problems there is a feature available on some switches that can help with this problem called persistent Poe in this episode of Cisco tech talk I'll explain persistent Poe on Cisco catalyst 00 series switches [Music] next persistent Poe also known as always on Poe minimizes downtime to keep operations smooth with persistent Poe a warm reboot of the switch will not interrupt the poe operation for the connected devices this includes using the reload command the reboot feature in the web user interface the reload with the device button or via a tool like Cisco business dashboard this means that when you perform an update or maintenance on your switch business can still proceed as normal with little to no downtime security cameras can stream employees have phone connections and the Wi-Fi clients are connected it's important to note that persistent Poe doesn't work in every situation if this switch reboots due to a factory reset or if the power cable is removed all connected devices will lose connectivity and power to learn more about this feature navigate to the port management menu on your Cisco Catalyst 1300 series switch there you will find the poe option under the poe settings you can see which ports are connected to Poe devices and how much power they're delivering for further details you can click on the help button which will take you to a page with more information about persistent Poe to provide a practical example I have a cbw 150 ax access point connected to my switch the MAC address of this access point ends with 1dec it is connected to port number three the access point has been up for over 4 hours while the switch has an up time of 16 minutes if I reboot the switch the access point will not reboot however it may lose connectivity for a few seconds or minutes depending on how quickly the switch comes back online to verify this I'll ping my switch and access point both respond indicating they are reachable next I'll reboot the switch I will go to the command prompt initiate the reboot and confirm it during the reboot process the Swit will lose connectivity and the access point will temporarily stop pinging this happens because once a reboot is initiated through the web user interface CLI tools or Cisco business dashboard the switch processor signals the power sourcing equipment controller that a reboot is about to start this helps maintain current power during the reboot during the warm reboot data connections from attached devices are lost devices like IP phones May display a disconnected message once the reboot is complete the switch restores the previous power State ensuring Poe doesn't need to be renegotiated data connectivity is then restored and the switch is fully online after the switch reboots it is up again and the access Point's reachability has also been restored the switch up Time Is Now 1 minute and 30 seconds while the the access point up time remains at 4 hours and 21 minutes confirming it did not reboot during the switch reboot if you see a blinking red icon to save the configuration make sure to click it to save your switch settings that's all there is to it one feature providing peace of mind and enhancing productivity for your business thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

transcript: by stacking switches you can simplify Network management increase redundancy and improve performance even though you may have multiple switches when they are stacked they are managed as a single entity this setup is especially beneficial in environments where uptime and reliability are crucial such as offices data centers or schools if you would like to set up stacking using the web user interface of the switches click the link in the descript description in this episode of Cisco tech talk I'll explain how to create a stack of two Catalyst 1300 switches via CLI [Music] next Catalyst 1300 switches allow you to stack up to eight devices before starting it's important to note that each switch must have the same firmware version and must belong to the same family type as indicated on the screen you can find this information in the Catalyst 1300 data sheet the link is in the description cross stacking between different families is not supported I will walk you through the process of forming a stack with two devices Begin by logging into switch one as you can see this device has only one VLAN created with an IP and all other configurations are set to default now go to the configure terminal mode the command to execute is stack configuration links followed by the interface range that will work as stack ports in this example I'll use 10 gig ports 11 to 12 with the unit ID the identifier for the device as one after entering the command the device will indicate that you need to reboot for the settings to take effect I will save the configuration first then reload the switch [Music] next go to switch two and repeat the process notice that I am using a comma between the interfaces instead of a range this way you can select several interfaces that are not continuous if needed save the configuration and then reload the switch for the settings to take effect after the devices are reloaded plug the cables into the stack ports after a few seconds the stack will be formed connect the console cable to unit one to check the stack you can use the commands show stack show stack configuration and show stack links it's important to note that connecting via CLI to a switch that is not active will not display any output and there you have it stacked switching providing a more streamlined and efficient Network management experience thanks for watching I'll see you next next time [Music]
