seconds with a default of 20 a longer duration may be best if you only have a small number of clients or if clients don't have stable connections a shorter time may be preferred if you want the network to be more responsive to changes or if you have a high number of clients to manage Beacon intervals can be set for the aps to buffer broadcast and multicast data they inform mobile devices when to wake up to receive data it optimizes battery life for mobile devices by reducing unnecessary wakeups the default value for this is one raising the number can benefit battery life and reduce overhead but it could lead to slower network discovery unstable connections and latency band selection enables dual band client radios of 2.4 and 5 GHz to move to less congested bands the purpose is to reduce interference and improve overall Network performance however several variables can cause issues and this may need adjusting client load balancing helps distribute clients across APS ensuring no single AP becomes overloaded this can lead to more consistent performance and better use of network resources however if you're finding that clients are getting dis connected or similar issues you could disable the setting to see how that affects the performance this next setting relates to Cisco umbrella a subscription service for cloud delivered security that helps protect your network from online threats within the context of cbw APs the umbrella profile options are typically used to configure security policies for your network choose none if no specific umbrella security policy is applied to the WL the Network traffic will not be filtered or monitored by Cisco umbrella select ignore for the system to bypass Cisco umbrella security policies when you don't want the umbrella policies to interfere with specific traffic or devices if you want to enforce the umbrella security policies on the W Lan choose forced it ensures that all Network traffic is subject to the filtering and monitoring roles set up in the cisal umbrella dashboard umbrella DHCP over ride ignores the DNS IPS configured via DHCP and forces the umbrella DNS IPS on the client device if you set umbrella mode to Forest you do not need to enable umbrella DHCP override for multicast settings you can enter a multicast IP Group address and enable multicast direct to enhance video streaming by converting multicast packets to unicast which provides smoother streaming be sure to have a good understanding of multicast traffic and IP group addressing if you use this feature the last four toggles are for mimo and ofdma these features are enabled by default to enhance Network performance allowing multiple devices to communicate simultaneously this can be a big benefit especially in highdensity environments these Technologies are most effective if most of the network and devices on it support these features if you decide to make any changes don't forget to save them to your AP that's all there is to it keep fine-tuning these Advanced options to ensure a smooth reliable and secure Wireless experience for all users thanks for watching I'll see you next time [Music]

tags: How to Recover my Password on Cisco switches
transcript: Your business relies on smooth network operations. So, losing access to your switch because of a forgotten password can cause a bit of panic, especially if you're new to managing network devices. Knowing how to recover a password can save you from unnecessary downtime and potential security risks. In this episode of Cisco Tech Talk, I'll show you how to perform password recovery for Catalyst 1200 and 1300 series switches. Next, [Music] for this example, I'll use a Windows PC. First, open the device manager on the PC and select ports. Once the computer is connected to the console port on the switch, identify which COM port is being used. In this example, it is COM 3. Next, open Putty and choose the connection type as serial. Ensure the serial line is COM 3 and set the speed to 115200. At the bottom, select serial. Leave the initial settings as default and set flow control to none. After the settings are configured, return to the session menu and click open. To proceed, restart the switch by unplugging the power source. Once you plug the power source back, the switch will begin booting. After a moment, a 2- second message will appear. Press enter to abort the process. You will now see the startup menu. Choose option three for the password recovery procedure and press enter. Then press escape to exit the boot menu and allow the switch to bypass the password and username requirement. After a few seconds, the switch will finish booting and you will have access to it. Enter the command enable and type config t. You can then change the password by typing the command username followed by the desired username. You can use the existing username or create a new one. Then enter the word password followed by the new password and set the privilege level to 15. The privilege level must be set to 15 to grant the user full access to the device. If not, a password will be required to access enable mode. The next time you log in, exit the global configuration mode. Save the changes with the command write and then select yes to confirm. Reboot the device by entering the command reload and confirm by typing Y for yes. Now you can access the switch with the username and password you created. It's important to note that if the no service password recovery has been configured, you can still access the boot menu and initiate the password recovery process. However, in this scenario, all configuration files and user files will be removed. That's it. Just a few simple steps for password recovery on your Catalyst 1200 or 1300 series switch. For more details on service password recovery, click the link in the description. Thanks for watching. I'll see you next time. [Music]

transcript: The Cisco Business mobile app is a userfriendly tool designed to simplify network setup, management, and monitoring of Cisco business devices. The app currently supports switches in the business 220, 250, and 350 series and the Catalyst 1200 and 1300 series. It also supports wireless access points and mesh extenders in the business 100 and 200 series. In this episode of Cisco Tech Talk, I'll give you an overview of the Cisco business mobile app. Next, [Music] this intuitive and easy to use application is supported on both Apple and Android platforms as a free download. It can set up wireless devices in minutes, view and modify your network configuration, and back up any changes. Access to realtime snapshots of network usage, traffic patterns, and alerts is always available. When you need to troubleshoot, some features within the app can be very helpful. Monitoring your network performance and throughput can be done with integrated speed testing. The app sets up an overview of your network topology. This helps you visualize connections, identify potential points of failure or bottlenecks in the network, see anything disconnected, trace paths for data, and assess changes in the network. You have the control to launch one job at a time, request job queuing, monitor the status of the queue, and view the history of completed jobs. You also have the option to roll back devices in case it is ever needed. Some additional features include detecting configuration mismatches between the devices and the app, allowing you to resolve these differences automatically or manually. The app can manage both brownfield deployments day n which refers to an existing network and greenfield deployments day zero for a new deployment. If you use the Cisco business dashboard CBD, you can tether it to the mobile app so you can view resources and information on the devices managed by CBD. Through the app, you will see alert and status information only as management will be done through the CBD instance. The app currently supports multiple languages including English, French, German, Japanese, simplified Chinese, Spanish, and Portuguese. In the future, if you need help with a configuration or feature, links to tech talk videos are available, as well as troubleshooting guides right within the app. Be sure to keep the app up to date with the latest version available to have access to the latest features and bug fixes. The Cisco Business Mobile app allows you to monitor your network and address any potential issues directly from your mobile device. It's that simple. Thanks for watching. I'll see you next time. [Music]

title: Cisco Tech Talk: Power over Ethernet (PoE) for Beginners
description:
Setting up your office with devices like IP phones, wireless access points, and security cameras can get messy with all those cables and power sources. But what if you could simplify it all? In this edition of Cisco Tech Talk, we’ll explain the basics of Power over Ethernet (PoE). 

Key advantages of PoE: 
Ease of Use: Simplifies setup by dealing with only one type of cable. Place devices like IP phones, wireless access points, and security cameras wherever needed, regardless of electrical outlets. 
Centralized Power Management: Control power to all your PoE devices from one central location, allowing you to easily reboot devices, turn them on or off, or adjust power consumption. This can lead to significant energy savings. 
Enhanced Safety: PoE systems intelligently manage power delivery, ensuring each device gets the right amount without risk of overload or damage. 
Say goodbye to tangled cables! PoE is the streamlined solution you need for a more efficient and manageable network setup.

transcript: When you're setting up an office or a home security system, you probably have devices like IP phones, wireless access points, and security cameras. You're excited about getting everything up and running. But then you realize each device needs both a network connection and a power source. The thought of dealing with all those cables and finding enough electrical outlets can be overwhelming, right? Well, this is where power over Ethernet, PoE, comes to the rescue. It's a nifty technology that can make your setup process a lot simpler and more efficient. In this episode of Cisco Tech Talk, I'll explain the basics of PoE. Next, [Music] so what exactly is power over Ethernet? Simply put, PoE allows you to deliver both power and data to devices using a single Ethernet cable. Normally, Ethernet cables are just for data, while power cables supply electricity. PoE combines these two functions, eliminating the need for separate power cords. This makes everything much easier to manage, especially in places where running lots of cables would be a hassle. Cisco offers several business class switches with PoE ports, including models in the business 110, 220, 250, and 350 series and the Catalyst 1200 and 1300 series. If a Cisco business class switch has PoE support, it will be signified with a P in the model number. Depending on the model, some or all of these ports may have PoE. They're typically designated by color or with a lightning bolt. One of the biggest advantages of PoE is its ease of use. Setting up devices becomes a lot more straightforward because you only have to deal with one type of cable. You can position devices like IP phones, wireless access points, and security cameras wherever you need without worrying about how to power them. This flexibility is invaluable in both professional and home settings. Imagine being able to place a security camera in the perfect spot for coverage, even if there isn't an electrical outlet nearby. With PoE, that's entirely possible. PoE isn't just about convenience. It's also about centralized power management. You can control the power to all your PoE devices from one central location. This means you can easily reboot devices, turn them on or off, or adjust their power consumption without having to physically go to each device. This centralized control can lead to significant energy savings over time, as you can power down devices when they're not needed. Safety is another key benefit of PoE. Traditional electrical wiring can pose risks like overloads or underpowering, which can damage equipment. PoE systems are designed to intelligently manage power delivery, ensuring that each device gets the right amount of power without the risk of overload or damage. This built-in safety feature provides peace of mind knowing that your equipment is protected. The installation process is simplified with PoE. Since you don't need a qualified electrician to lay down network cables, it's easier and more cost-effective to set up your network. This can be particularly beneficial in larger installations such as office buildings or campuses where the cost and complexity of electrical wiring can be significant. Additionally, PoE offers enhanced control and monitoring. Features like perport power consumption control and Cisco PoE MIB's management information bases let you monitor and manage power usage proactively. This means you can see how much power each device is using and adjust as needed, further optimizing your energy use and saving on costs. So, next time you find yourself tangled in a mess of cables, remember that PoE might just be the streamlined solution you need. Thanks for watching. I'll see you next time. [Music]

title: Cisco Tech Talk: How to Change Your DNS Settings with Google DNS, OpenDNS & Cloudflare - Part 1
description:
Are you looking to boost your internet speed, reliability, and security? In this first of a two-part series of Cisco Tech Talk, we break down what the Domain Name System (DNS) is and show you step-by-step how to change your DNS settings on Windows, iPhone (iOS 17), and Android (Android 14) devices using popular public DNS servers like Google DNS, OpenDNS, and Cloudflare. 
 
Stay tuned for part 2 next week!

transcript: The domain name system DNS is like the internet's phone book. When an easily remembered website like cisco.com is entered into a browser, it looks up its corresponding unique IP address and changes the search to that address. This is necessary for devices to communicate with other devices on the internet. Most businesses use the default DNS servers that come with their internet service provider ISP for this. However, there are public DNS servers you can use instead, which can provide some good benefits. In this first of a two-part episode of Cisco Tech Talk, I'll explain some benefits of using a public DNS server and show you how to change it on some individual devices. Next, [Music] Public DNS servers are managed by thirdparty companies and are open for anyone to use. They can be a good alternative. Public DNS servers often load websites faster, have better uptime and fewer outages, and may even provide additional security and privacy. Some of the most popular are Google DNS, Open DNS and Cloudflare. They provide both IPv4 and IPv6 addresses. You can change the DNS server on different devices. Where you change the DNS settings depends on how widely you want the changes to apply and how much control you need. I will demonstrate the process on a few different devices. To keep it simple, I will use Google DNS for all of them. You can set a Windows computer to use a public DNS server with a few simple steps. Open the control panel on your computer. Select network and internet and then network connections. Doubleclick on your connection. Click properties. I'll select the IPv4 option. Enter the DNS server addresses you prefer. I'll enter 8.8. 8.8.8 as the preferred DNS server and 8.8.4.4 as the alternate. This setting applies to this one computer. You can also change your cell phone to use a public DNS server. To set this up on an iPhone iOS version 17, open settings, select the wireless network, and click the I next to the network name. Scroll down and select configure DNS. Choose manual. Delete the existing DNS server address and enter the public DNS server addresses. Click save in the top right corner of the screen. To change the DNS settings on an Android version 14, start by scrolling down the menu and selecting Wi-Fi. Choose the SSID that you're connected to. Click on settings, then view more options. If you are using DHCP, like in this example, you can't change the DNS settings. Switch this over to static. Keep this same IP address as before and ensure the gateway remains unchanged. For DNS, I'll switch to the public DNS server and then click save to apply the changes. Depending on your device and software version, these new settings may not transfer when you connect to a new wireless network. If they don't, you'll need to repeat the steps to apply when using this new network. That's all there is to it. With just a few steps, you can enjoy the benefits of using a public DNS server for your device. For a bigger impact, you can set your router so all devices using that router will use the public DNS server. I'll cover that in part two. The link is in the description. Thanks for watching. I'll see you soon. [Music]

title: Cisco Tech Talk: How to Change Your DNS Settings with Google DNS, OpenDNS & Cloudflare - Part 2
description:
Welcome back to Cisco Tech Talk! In part two of our DNS series, learn how to change DNS settings on your entire network. Switching to a public DNS like Google DNS ensures every device—PCs, smartphones, printers, smart home gadgets—enjoys faster speeds, better uptime, and enhanced security. 

Why Change DNS at the Router Level? 
Changing the DNS server at the router level means every device that connects to your Wi-Fi network will automatically use your chosen public DNS server, like Google DNS, OpenDNS, or Cloudflare DNS, without needing to configure each device individually. 

Missed part 1? Watch it here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hqxy7nL3gGo]

transcript: Welcome back. In part one, I explained the benefits of using a public DNS server and how to change it on an individual device. By changing the DNS at the router level, you ensure that every device on your network benefits from the potentially faster, more reliable, and secure public DNS servers. In this episode of Cisco Tech Talk, I'll show you how to change DNS servers on an RV 160 wireless ACVPN router. Next, [Music] to change your RV 160 router to use a public DNS, start by accessing the router's web interface. If you know your router's IP address, open a browser and type it in. If you're unsure of the IP address, you can find it by going to the command prompt on your computer. Type ipconfig/all on Windows or if config on Mac or Linux. You can often look for the default gateway under your Ethernet adapter. Common IP addresses for routers are 192.168.1.1, 192.168.0.1 0.1 or 10.0.0.1. However, it is important to note that in some scenarios, the default gateway on the PC will point to another device. If you use a router from your service provider, the IP address may be printed on the router itself or the manual that came with it. Once you have the IP address, enter it into your browser's address bar. You'll be prompted to log in with your username and password. After logging in, look for the DNS settings on the interface which are located on the main page for this model. This is for the WAN interface. The DNS server option will be available under the WAN settings page. Currently, you're most likely using the DNS provided by your internet service provider. To change it, select the use DNS as below checkbox and enter the new address. For Google's public DNS server, that's 8.8.8.8. For a secondary DNS, enter 8.8.4.4. Click the apply button to save the changes to the running configuration file. To save the changes on the startup configuration file, click the red save icon at the top of the page. Restart the router to verify that the changes took effect. Under the administration menu, the reboot option will be available. Click reboot. Select reboot the device. Click reboot and confirm by clicking okay. The router will restart, so you'll need to wait a few moments. Once the router is back online, log in again to confirm that the DNS changes have been applied successfully. Now your router should be using the new public DNS server settings. There you have it. Now devices such as computers, smartphones, smart devices, and printers connected to the network will automatically use the new DNS settings. Thanks for watching. I'll see you next time. [Music]

title: Cisco Tech Talk: CBW Access Point Channels for Beginners - Part 1
description:
In this first episode of a two-part series of Cisco Tech Talk, we break down how wireless channels work, the differences between 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz frequency bands and why choosing the right Wi-Fi channel is key to boosting your network’s performance. 
What are Wireless Channels and Why Do They Matter? 
Think of wireless channels as lanes on a highway—using the right lane helps your data move faster and with less congestion. Selecting the optimal channel on your Cisco Business Wireless (CBW) access points can reduce Wi-Fi interference, improve Wi-Fi speed, and ensure reliable connectivity, especially in crowded environments. 

Stay tuned for part 2, where we’ll show you how to configure wireless channels on your Cisco Business Wireless access point for the best results.

transcript: Ever been in a crowded room and tried to have a private conversation? With so many people talking at the same time, it can be hard to hear. For a clear connection, spreading out into a less congested area makes sense. In this same way, wireless channels help devices communicate without interference. You could think of these channels as distinct lanes on a highway. By choosing the right lane or channel, data can travel smoothly. This is crucial for ensuring reliable connectivity, reducing interference, and improving speed, especially in environments with many devices. Setting up and fine-tuning wireless channels enhances your network's efficiency and strength, ensuring smooth communication for all connected devices. In this first of a two-part episode of Cisco Tech Talk, I'll explain Cisco Business Wireless CBW access point channels. Next, [Music] when setting up your wireless network, there is no one magic channel to choose for optimal performance. There are just too many factors that come into play. In a business environment, interference can come from neighboring Wi-Fi networks, electronic devices, or even physical obstacles like walls. Such interference can slow down your network, leading to frustrating delays or dropped connections. To combat this, it's essential to select the right wireless channels. CBW access points offer channels in two main frequency bands, 2.4 4 and 5 GHz. On the 2.4 GHz band, you can select channels from 1 to 11. While there are additional channels available, their availability depends on the region. In some parts of the world, channels up to 14 are offered, but only channels 1, 6, and 11 are considered non-over overlapping in most regions. This makes them ideal choices to reduce interference. To explain this further, the following visual shows that the channels in the 2.4 GHz band are spaced 5 MHz apart. Channel 1 has a frequency range from 2401 MHz to 2423 MHz. So, channel 5 with its starting frequency of 2421 MHz overlaps with channel 1. But channel 6 starts at 2426 MHz which doesn't overlap with channel 1. Similarly, channel 11 starts at 2451 MHz. It doesn't overlap with channel 6. The 2.4 GHz channels cover a larger area and can give access to devices that are further from the access point. They can penetrate walls and other obstacles more effectively. Some older devices need 2.4 GHz for compatibility. If the primary use of your network is for low bandwidth applications like web browsing, email or simple internet devices, this channel may be preferred since range can be more important than speed. The downside of the 2.4 4 GHz band is that it is more susceptible to interference because it is used by a lot of other devices such as microwaves and Bluetooth devices. Now, the 5 GHz band offers several advantages as well. One of the primary benefits is reduced congestion since it provides more available channels. This reduces the likelihood of interference from neighboring networks, enhancing the stability and speed of your connection. Speaking of speed, the 5 GHz band supports higher data rates, making it ideal for high bandwidth needs like video conferencing, cloud computing, and large file transfers. Many modern routers operating on the 5 GHz band also support advanced technologies like mumimo which stands for multi-user multiple input multiple output. It allows simultaneous efficient data transmission to multiple devices. The shorter range compared to the 2.4 4 GHz band and the fact that it may not penetrate walls and obstacles as effectively makes it a good option if your router and devices are relatively close to each other and you need a stable and fast connection within this range. That's a quick overview of the advantages and limitations of the 2.4 and 5 GHz bands. Click the link in the description for part two where I'll explain wireless channel configuration options on your CBWAP. Thanks for watching. I'll see you soon. [Music]

title: Cisco Tech Talk: How to Configure SNMPv2x on Cisco Catalyst 1200/1300 Switch - Part 1
description:
Welcome to part 1 of our 2-part Cisco Tech Talk series on configuring Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMPv2c) on Cisco Catalyst 1200 and 1300 switches. This video guides you through the essentials of SNMP, compares SNMPv2c and SNMPv3, and provides a step-by-step demonstration for setting up SNMPv2c to improve your network management and monitoring. 

In this episode (Part 1 of 2), you’ll learn: 
What is SNMP, and why is it important? 
Key differences between SNMPv2c and SNMPv3 
How to access and navigate the Catalyst switch GUI 
How to configure system location, contact, and hostname in the MIB 
How to enable SNMP services and configure SNMP views, groups, and communities 
Methods to include or exclude specific OIDs from SNMP polling 
This episode is perfect for network admins and IT professionals looking to optimize their Cisco switch setup and SNMP configuration. 

Stay tuned for part 2!

#CiscoTechTalk #SNMP #CiscoSwitch #NetworkManagement #Catalyst1200 #Catalyst1300 #SNMPv2c #NetworkMonitoring
transcript: The simple network management protocol SNMP is a protocol used for managing and monitoring devices on a network which is especially handy in local networks. It helps with efficient operation of various devices through switches. SNMP v2c and SNMP v3 are the most commonly used versions today. At its core, SNMP V2C is known for its simplicity and ease of use, making it a popular choice for those who prefer straightforward setups. However, if security is a high priority, SNMP V3 may be a better fit. Understanding these differences can help you select the right version for your needs. If you are new to SNMP or unsure about which version to choose, you can learn more by clicking the link in the description. In this first of a two-part episode of Cisco Tech Talk, I'll show you how to configure SNMP V2C on a Catalyst 1200 or 1300 switch. Next, [Music] log into the graphical user interface guey of your switch. In this demonstration, I'll be using a Catalyst 1200 switch running firmware version 4.1.4.1. I am currently in basic view, which is fine for now. Navigate to the status and statistics section, then system summary. Here you'll find the system information section. It contains the data to collect using SNMP. The information includes system description, location, contact, host name, object ID, and uptime. Configure the system location, system contact and host name parameters so that these changes reflect in the system management information base MIB results after configuration and SNMP testing. Next, access the administration section and select system settings. Here you can configure the system location, system contact and host name values. Either use the default values or enter custom ones. I will configure these parameters to demonstrate how they work and click apply. Return to status and statistics then system summary to confirm that the information has been updated with the newly configured values. To activate SNMP, go to security and then TCP UDP services. Select the SNMP service option. The enable check box is unchecked. So click it and hit apply to activate the SNMP protocol. Under service name, you will see SNMP listed. Port 161 will be open in the UDP service table below. To configure SNMP version 2, switch to the advanced view in the GUI. At the end of the menu, the SNMP option will show providing configuration options. I will use views, groups, and communities. Starting with views, you will see the Catalyst 1200 has default SNMP views named default and default super. I'll create a new view to demonstrate how to allow all SNMP MIBs and then block a couple of object identifiers, oids. The target MIB will be system. I'll exclude two of its oids. Click the plus icon to create a view. Enter a name for the view to identify it and its purpose. Select userdefined and enter the number one which represents ISO in SNMP allowing all SNMP MIBs. Ensure the include in view check box is checked to allow all MIBs. Click apply when ready. Next, I'll exclude the two oids from the system MIB so they don't appear in the SNMP polling. Enter the view name again. Select userdefined and type the oid value to exclude. Uncheck the include in view box to exclude the oids. Click apply and repeat for the remaining oids. Close the window and the switch will show the configuration details. You can filter SNMP views to display data for the newly created view. That brings me to the end of part one. Click the link in the description for part two where I'll wrap up configurations and conduct some verification tests using SNMP version 2C. Thanks for watching. I'll see you soon. [Music]

title: Cisco Tech Talk: How to Configure SNMPv2x on Cisco Catalyst 1200/1300 Switch - Part 2
description:
Welcome to part 2 of our Cisco Tech Talk series on configuring Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMPv2c) on Cisco Catalyst 1200 and 1300 switches.! In this episode, we complete the SNMPv2c configuration, demonstrate real-world SNMP polling tests, and show you how to manage SNMP communities and groups for more secure and flexible network monitoring. 

In this episode (Part 2 of 2), you’ll learn: 
How to configure SNMP communities with different access levels (Read Only, Read Write) 
How to create SNMP groups and assign security models 
Best practices for using SNMP views to control access to MIB objects 
How to verify SNMPv2c operation using third-party tools like Paessler SNMP Tester 
Key differences between SNMP community strings and views 
How to confirm your SNMPv2c setup is working on Catalyst 1200/1300 switches 

This step-by-step tutorial is perfect for IT professionals, network administrators, and anyone looking to enhance their Cisco switch SNMP setup for efficient device monitoring and management.

transcript: Welcome back. In this second of a two-part episode of Cisco Tech Talk, I'll complete configuration of SNMP V2C on a Catalyst 1200 or 1300 switch. Next, still on the graphical user interface of the switch in advanced mode, configure the communities option to create three strings showcasing different options. Click the plus icon to configure parameters for the SNMP management station. Choose userdefined allowing configuration of who collects data from the switch via SNMP. Use your laptop's IP address for the IP address parameter. Enter a community string value. Set access mode to read only and select the newly created view. Click apply to create the first community string. The community table will summarize the configuration. Next, create another community string with read write permission and the default super view. Observe the switch's behavior. A community string with read write access mode becomes SNMP admin by default. Now create an SNMP version 2 group. In the groups option, click the plus icon in the group table. Name the SNMP group and set the security model to SNMP version 2 as you are using community strings. This automatically sets the security level to no authentication and no privacy allowing configuration of the read and write view. The notify option is unnecessary here. Click apply and close the window once configured. Return to the communities option. Complete the required parameters and create your community string. Set access mode to read write and select advanced to show the group name created earlier. Click apply again. Selecting read write access mode changes it to SNMP admin. Great. Everything is set. For verification, I will do some SNMP polling tests using Pacer SNMP tester, a third party application. It's important to note that this application is not supported by Cisco. It is being used for demonstration purposes only. I have it preconfigured with parameters such as my laptop's local IP address and the switch's IP address for SNMP version 2. In the community field, I'll enter the strings configured on the switch. Start with the first string, the readonly one, and use the custom view to query the device uptime. Verify that the CIS uptime instance value in SNMP matches the system uptime value on the GUI confirming SNMP is operational. Next, change the option to walk. Enter the OID for the system and run the query. Check it out. When you review the results, you see that system description, location, contact, host name, object ID, and uptime match between the tool and the switch guey. This confirms that SNMP version 2C is functioning. Now query the switch with the second community string, the read write one, which has SNMP admin access mode and uses the default super view. Observe that the system output is larger compared to using a limited view community string. This illustrates the difference between views. With the second string, more data is visible than with the first string, confirming the SNMP view configuration is correct. Lastly, query the switch with the third community string linked to an SNMP group using the limited view created earlier. The result will match the first string due to the SNMP view configuration. There you have it. SNMP version 2 is configured and properly running on your Catalyst 1200 or 1300 switch. If you ever decide that you need the security of version 3 instead, click the link in the description for configuration details. Thanks for watching. I'll see you next time.

transcript: Welcome back. In part one, I gave an overview of the channel bands available on Cisco Business Wireless CBW access points and how proper selection can minimize interference and maximize performance. In this second of a two-part episode of Cisco Tech Talk, I'll explain some configuration options on your CBW access point. Next, Today I'll be configuring these settings on a CBW 150 access point. Log in and navigate to the access point menu. In this example, you can see the primary AP is operating on channel 1 while the mesh extender operates on channel 11. Clicking on an access point will show the channels selected for both the 2.4 4 GHz and 5 GHz radios. Troubleshooting options are available to identify nearby access points that could interfere with your device. The RF troubleshoot tool displays neighboring and rogue access points, helping you find sources of interference that might degrade performance. To change the channel settings on an access point, go to the wireless settings, select the access point, and click edit. You'll see two radios, one for the 2.4 GHz band and one for the 5 GHz band. Channels can be set to automatic or manually selected from available options. Manually selecting channels can be complex if you aren't familiar with them. Automatic channel selection allows your access point to choose the best channel by scanning the environment to find the least congested one. This improves performance, ensuring your network runs smoothly. It also offers adaptability as the access point can adjust the channel to maintain optimal performance as the environment changes, such as when new networks appear. Consider using automatic channel selection if you are unsure about which ones to choose. It simplifies the setup process and optimizes performance. A few things to note. In the 5 GHz band, some channels are marked as DFS, dynamic frequency selection, which means they automatically adjust to avoid interference. If you are not using mesh extenders in your network, this can be disabled. Automatic channel assignments are supported in non- mesh deployments.
